I was happy with the service -- we were always greeted with an "hola" or "buenos tardes." Then again, if you walk around with a smile on your face, you're more likely to see a smile back. We're definitely going back to Fairmont Mayakoba in the future. It is good for couples but has potential for a family getaway as well.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful property, friendly, professional staff, lovely rooms”
Reviews.Author: EasilyAmused
Reviews.Content: Although we've traveled all over the world, we had never been to Mexico. We weren't disappointed. We traveled with our 5-year-old and were looking for an upscale, family friendly hotel for a four day getaway. From the moment we checked in until our departure, we enjoyed every minute of our stay. Service was extremely professional and warm but relaxed. The extensive grounds are very well maintained. Shuttle service was prompt. Our room, kn a casita, was lovely, and despite the fact that it really had no view, it was lovely, clean and spacious with ample room for the three of us. Bathroom was glorious, almost as large as the bedroom area. Housekeeping was top notch with the one quibble that turn down service takes place until 9:30PM - on the nights we were back from dinner before 9pm, we declined the service as we were in the process of putting our child to bed. The property is very large and spread out, and while this allows for ample privacy, it also means that everything is a schlepp. Our casita was right in the middle of the property, equidistant from the main building and the beach. As such, I opted not to use the gym - on vacation I don't want to have to work too hard to actually get to the gym. Regardless, the atmosphere is very peaceful. Food was very good - lovely breakfast spread with fresh fruits, breads, pastries, yogurts and many hot offerings. The "family style" dinner listed on the back of the menu was a relative bargain and the food was fantastic.. Pools and beach were all well maintained with efficient service. Sign up for the little boat tour of the Mayakoba property when you arrive - the boat only accommodates 4 people at a time and only runs a few times in the early morning. It was a great way to see more of the property and some wildlife to boot. All in all we really enjoyed our stay. We did a few days trips so we didn't have as much time to use all the facilities but we would happily return either as a family or just as a couple. Lovely experience.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent”
Reviews.Author: roofen
Reviews.Content: not alot to say fairmount mayakoba other then if you paln to visit mexico you will be missing out if you dont stay a this resort i cant think about anything negitive to stay from the rooms to the service its all good go to the mayakoba and have a great time

Reviews.Title: “Absolutely Beautiful with the Impeccable Grounds and Service”
Reviews.Author: DCLuvs2Travel
Reviews.Content: From the moment we arrived at the Fairmont Mayakoba, we were amazed by its beauty and by the service of its employees. Gustavo, our bellhop, greeted us upon arrival and was welcoming, accomodating and treated us as if we were the only guests staying there. Upon entering the main lobby for the first time, we were blown away by the luxury and style of the hotel -- and this sentiment remained with us throughout our four-day vacation. Service is the name of the game at the Fairmont Mayakoba -- anything you need, they will provide, and more importantly, they anticipate before you even ask. From room service, to pool-side lounging, there is someone friendly and eager to help with anything. The employees are lovely and seem genuinely happy to assist in any way. The most impressive part of the hotel were the grounds -- absolutely stunning. The pools, the beach, the buildings and the landscaping were impeccably built and maintained and it really felt like we were completely removed from everything else. The food was good and fairly reasonably priced -- keep in mind that we didn't eat at the main lodge restaurant which offered more fine-dining cuisine. The menu was impressive however. The Mayakoba is a wonderful getaway for those who are looking to travel with family or just as a romantic getaway. We can't wait to go back!

Reviews.Title: “Mexico experience”
Reviews.Author: SDSBelgium
Reviews.Content: Super service - very friendly and supportive staff Excellent food and great cocktails!

Reviews.Title: “Heaven in the Tropics”
Reviews.Author: CultivatedSurfNTURF
Reviews.Content: Our family with young children (9 & 10),spent the week before Christmas at the Mayakoba. From the moment we made our reservation Marco the concierge attended to our every need. Without being pushy he requested and arranged airport transfers and other transportation. He also sent us a packet detailing all the holiday festivities the hotel had planned. When we arrived we were graciously greeted by the friendly bell staff with cold towels and refreshing juice. Both served from silver trays. This along with the breathtaking lobby was a big "wow" moment for all of us after our long flight. In short, we knew we had made the right decision as to where to spend our holiday. The hotel grounds and rooms are very well kept with very nice toiletries and linens in the spacious rooms. The management must be very careful in who they select to work at the hotel because EVERYONE IS POLITE, FRIENDLY, AND HELPFUL. It is nothing short of amazing how management has pulled this great feat off. EVERYONE greets you with a smile and "Buenos Dias". No one has the snobby, superior demeanor so often encountered at a five star resort. Heaven!! The kids had a blast at the slide pool and the Kids' Club which has a wonderful staff. The other pools were lovely as they are set up amid a series of walkways and chaise seating areas so that the effect is a series of large pool "rooms". Also there is a stunning elevated adult pool off to itself in a gorgeous location. The beach is a whole other environment if you need a change from the pool. Shuttles carry guests back and forth a short distance to the beach area. You can also walk from the hotel on a wide concrete path through the jungle to the beach. Surreal, especially at sunset. Staff sets you up on the beach or at the beach pool and brings you all the food and drink you desire. There is also a lovely large palapa restaurant with an al fresco bar. On the beach you can walk several miles in either direction. As you do you will note that the Mayakoba F. has one of thee best beach locations in Playa del Carmen. The holiday festivities were nothing short of amazing. Suffice to say that the hotel takes its programs VERY SERIOUSLY. I'll never forget the evening when the mayans in full dress cruised up the river chanting and offering incense while a chorus of hotel staff blew conch shell 'horns'. This was preceded by an operetta of Christmas carols and the evening finished off with Mariachis arriving by the boatload. All the while guests were served appetizers and offered a traditional Christmas drink. Very memorable! The travel desk is very helpful, friendly, and again Not Pushy. Enough cannot be said about the incredible service of our concierge Marco. He is the frosting on the cake at this heaven in the tropics.

Reviews.Title: “Simply suberb!”
Reviews.Author: Chenchomelo
Reviews.Content: I'd been to Mayakobá Hotel in August 2006 but hadn't really had the chance to get to know the hotel and besides my stay was quite brief. I was visiting with friends and were out most of the time. But the mystique and the overall atmosphere didn't go unnoticed. While making our wedding plans on May 2009 Makayobá came up as an option for our honeymoon destination and it turned out to be the perfect choice. This place is simply magical! It is surrounded by natural lakes and mangroves and most of the suites have a view to these natural beauties. When you're in Mayakobá the outside world is far from reach and you're taken into a secret world where romance and serenity are at every corner. Because we visited the hotel during a low occupation month the hotel was practically all to ourselves. The service was simply superb and every detail was strictly supervised by their staff. They always addressed us by our last names which I should note because at other hotels they hardly notice you're even there. The hotel is quite pricey but it's worth every penny. I'd definitely recommend it and look forward to staying there every time I visit Playa del Carmen.

Reviews.Title: “Good and Bad”
Reviews.Author: lisared
Reviews.Content: I recently visited Playa Del Carmen, Mexico with my mom. I decided to stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba after i found a great deal on the web..friends and family and paid $199 per nite (plus numberous tax add ons= total was $253 per nite) We arrived from Newark direct on Continental and paid $650 r/t per person. The plane was filled with children , but that is what we should have expected at that time of year (christmas to new years 2010) I travel quite a bit for work , so i always have high expectations. The hotel was quite large, and i was a bit taken aback when i realized how far it was from the beach. It seemed more like a "compound" than a 5-star hotel. My initial opinion warmed after the first day as the layout became more familiar. The food, as other writer's have commented is expensive. You can have breakfast at either Las Brisas or La Luna , both will run you $50 for 2 people (buffet + tip) My mom and I are not huge eaters so we just got coffee and pasteries....we paid $20 per day. We also rented a car, which i do recommend, although that too was quite costly. I rented from ACE RENT A CAR online before we left (booked in October for December travel) and got a rate of $145 for 7 days unlimited mileage. When we arrived at the rent a car place after taking the bus from the airport, they were not too friendly. The car they assigned us too was quite small and manual (good thing i remembered!) + they informed me that there is a "mandatory" liability insurance which brough my rate from $145 to 215..i was not a happy camper...so back to the hotel...i requested an upgrade and they said no problem. the check in time was 3pm , i arrived at 3:45pm but room was not ready. They agreed (after i requested) to buy us drinks for our wait...we arrrived at our "tree house" at about 4:30pm. The room was very nice, mini-bar (nothing in it which i found quite strange) and nice big bathroom with jacquizzi tub..lots of windows for light, bed was extremely comfortable with sufficient amount of pillows...there were a few things...out on our deck were two cushioned chairs, but the cushions where filled with "stains" when i called the front desk they immediately sent someone to remove and wash them...i thought the response was o.k.but i would have preferred to just have clean cushions. I then called to see if there were any casita's on the lagoon (very nice) . No one got back to me and i grew frustrated.. If it's avail, tell me , If there is a charge ,tell me but no communication is not acceptable from a 5 star resort. I also requested dinner reservations at the nearby Rosewood (beautiful!!! although $700 per nite) Mayakoba. Again , i rec'd mixed messages...they are booked until the new year..well, I was there until Jan. 4 so told Yuki at the Conceirge desk, that's fine pls book us the 2nd or the 3rd....never heard back. Finally , I called and said i needed to have resolution in regards to our dinner plans..finally she left me a message , we were booked for El Puerto (at Fairmont) on New Year's Eve at 7:00pm and at the Rosewood restaurant for Jan . 2 ...i shouldn' t have to call back, this is a deluxe resort..so communication is key, as i told the manager who called to apologize after i grew weary of the resort and emailed the head office. On a brighter note..the bikes they have all around the resort are great, although there is only one size bike. You can pick it up at the transportation center, or at the main pool or at the beach and ride it to your destination and then leave it for the next rider. There were fireworks scheduled for New Year's Eve, but when i asked someone at the transportation center where they were, they had no idea. After I asked a second person , they also were confused..i don't blame the individual workers, but the management for not keeping their employees updated. Overall they eventually upgraded our room to a casita on the lagoon . My mom loved it she could feed the fish and looking at the water from the deck was so peaceful and relaxing. The business center, although they said it was "free" they do charge you , so again the employee (alexis) who gave me that info was misinformed. They not only charge you for print outs, but they also charge you for use *by time of the computers....Another interesting point is that Playa Del Carmen is about 12 min south of the hotel..there are restaurants there (try the Ladybug) which are a much better value than the hotel. Once reviewing advised "THE FUSION " on the beach..i made my mom hike down quite a ways to this hotel / restaurant , but would only rate it mediocre. I also took a drive to TULUM (about 1.15 hours from Mayakoba) since i had friends staying at the Maya Tulum..It reminded me slightly of Costa Rica, but I could see it was becoming too commercialized....restaurant food (zuma's) was not as good as 10 yrs ago, and there were tour buses turning around on the one main road..there also was a bit of litter scattered..so i ask..what's next? Punta Allen? Good luck !! lisa

Reviews.Title: “Great service bur surprisingly poor food quality”
Reviews.Author: hookturn
Reviews.Content: The service and location were all excellent and in particular the room cleaning was very efficient. We were always impressed by how quickly and thoroughly the room was cleaned. However the whole food and drink experience was awful. The food at the hotel was very sub standard and there seems to have been lots of corners cut on quality. We left pretty much all of our meals half eaten and we tried all three restaurants. The drink orders were always short and the pours were very weak. We ended up eating at the Rosewood and the Banyan for the last two days as we didn’t want another bad experience. At the rate they charged we were very surprised to see the Fairmont cut corners on soemthing as basic as food and drink.

Reviews.Title: “Hard to judge a resort Xmas week, but nice overall”
Reviews.Author: PennAndUCLAGrad
Reviews.Content: My husband and I are newlyweds and went for a relaxing week away the last week of the year. This resort is very nice, and beautifully situated on a gorgeous beach. It may be a bit too heavily skewed towards families, but hard to tell that week, when probably most resorts are teeming with kids. The room was very nice, with a very grand marble bathroom with tons of natural light. We had a deluxe casita rate but were upgraded to a signature Casita and I am not sure how different it was from what we'd booked. The room had an odor for sure, but perhaps in that climate it's unavoidable. Most of the rooms at this hotel are far from and do not overlook the ocean. However, the golf carts ran frequently, and you can also pick up a bike from one of the many racks around the property, and get a few minutes of exercise while riding to the beach (you don;t have to check out the bikes, you just grab one if its available, and leave it at your next spot). The main pool seemed very nice, but it is in the center of the property away from the beach, so we chose not to take advantage of it. Unfortunately, the pool at the beach, while nice, is a bit small (and not heated in winter). The food in the restaurants was good but not excellent. The "four diamond" el puerto was actually a big letdown, but others mentioned they had good meals there. We went into town 4 of 6 nights, and highly recommend doing so. The taxi ride is 170 pesos each way, but the restaurants are very reasonable so you make up a little bit of what you would have spent in inflated prices at the hotel (plus it's much more lively and fun in town). The hotel likes to recommend a Mayan place called Yac-she (sp?) but we weren't that impressed. We were much happier just to walk along the main avenue and choose based on the menus we liked. The place was at 100% capacity, and therefore a bit hectic. That being said, the ONLY time it really felt hectic was on the beach...otherwise the property is so spread out you wouldnt know how full it is. Neither having to walk the beach trying to find an empty lounge chair nor waking up early to go down to the beach and hold chairs is very relaxing. It just seemed like a problem that could be fixed by an investment in another 20-25 chairs. When I suggested they bring some chairs down from the adult pool (which was empty, I think because of the location within the resort) they said it would be too hard to move them. While this resort is top notch, if you're the type who likes the best of the best, you may be slightly bothered by the fact that the resort is flanked on either side by superior resorts. The Banyan Tree and Rosewood are smaller, newer, and a cut above (We noticed that both the BT and RW had service people sweeping their beachfronts for trash and kelp, but the Fairmont did not). Those resorts also have more comfy looking lounge chairs on the beach. Apparently during normal weeks the hotel will shuttle you back and forth between those resorts, where you can go for meals, but during xmas they were not allowing this and the restaurants weren't taking reservations from non-guests.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful property and grounds a relaxing oasis”
Reviews.Author: Reader62
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a wonderful vacation at the Fairmont. I traveled with husband 3 teenage children and grandparents. The resort is very large but that was a plus for us. We were able to talke long walks around the property and the beach. The tram was always availabe if someone did not want to walk. The beach is beautiful. Hardly any rocks able to walk right into water. The hotel staff was amazing making our stay delightful. We ate delicious meals at all 3 restaurants . In addition we went into playa del carma for some dinners. Our favorite was Cas Agua. The only thing that could use improving was the tennis courts. Only 2 for three resorts and a slippery surface. Would recommend hotel for anyone who wants some relaxation.

Reviews.Title: “would come back, but did not live up to expectation”
Reviews.Author: Phoebeling
Reviews.Content: Although overall we had an enjoyable vacation, I am uncertain that the resort lived up to Fairmont Hotel of the Year in 2008 based on our experiences with other Fairmont properties. Undoubtedly, the resort is a beautiful property and locale, but... My wife and I were planning to come down for the Christmas week and made reservations in a signature casita when our daughter decided to join us. We contacted the concierge requesting a possible upgrade to a larger suite, and although I understand that the resort was actually full for the holiday week, we were never contacted about lack of availability despite being reassured through mulitple emails that someone would be contacting us and that the hotel staff were working on it. Then despite our having requested queen beds, when we arrived we were told that we had been placed in a king bed, which was not acceptable given our daughter's arrival. We had communicted these specific issues in numerous emails prior to arrival. We then had to wait over 2 hours in the lobby lounge waiting for a room with queen beds to be made available. We were told by desk staff that the reason our room took so long to prepare was because of the "dirty" and filthy condition the room had been left in b y the previous vacationers- not the best way to welcome someone to the resort, telling them how dirty the room was you will now be staying in. As we were waiting, both my wife and daughter were devoured by mosquitos in the balcony area of the lobby lounge. The mosquitos were an issue through much of the stay leading us to cancel reservations for outddor dinner activities. We had read a previous review which had reported problems with mosquitos, responded to by hotel staff as reassuring travelers that the problem had been addressed by the scientsits/environmentalists involved in the design of this community. Staff were attentive at times, sometimes too much so, sometimes not as much as would be expected from a five star property. Overall, I would still say the service was favorable, though my wife would disagree. My wife had a bad experience at the spa. She has back problems and made people aware of this on numerous occasions and was reassured that she would feel so much better after a treatment. She was concerned about staff's ability to speak english so that she could let people know about her health concerns and give specific directions concerning what she might be able to tolerate. She was again reassured that this would not be a problem. Unfortunately she tolerated only a few minutes if not moments of her treatment and had to be transported back to our room via cart because she was unable to walk (oxygen was rushed into the room at the spa because staff were uncertain of her medical status). My daughter and I were more fortunate than my wife and had positive experiences at the spa enjoying our treatments. The spa was a wonderful, relaxing environment though treatments were not inexpensive. I would recommend the Cha Cha rain ritual to anyone interested in an incredibly relaxing treatment. There did seem to be pressure exerted by staff to fill open treatment slots, though we were allowed to reschedule or cancel my wife's appointments after her mishap. Also we did wind up putting a block on phone calls to our room, due to repeated calls to confirm various dinner apppointments, golf reservations, and spa treatments. There is a line between attentiveness vs. follow up creating the impression the resort simply wants to make certain they can extract as much in fees as possible for various activities. Again some of this may have been due to the resort being full for parts of the holiday week and the resort wanting to make certain that open slots for various activities were minimized, but it was difficult for my wife to relax in the room with the numerous calls/messages. The room and bathroom were lovelyl, though the marble floor could have been washed and kept cleaner, our feet getting dirty (black) when not wearing the resort provided slippers. food at the resort was good and in my opinion relatively inexpensive for Caribbbean destinations. I suspect that the food bill was less than if we had stayed at an all inclusive with preferrable quality. Our favorite restaurant was the Puerta restaurant which had the widest selections on the menu. My daughter enjoyed the scenic boat ride through the freshwater canals. The beach was crowded the days we went and ideally there could have been additonal lounges made available. Hotel guests should not be left wandering the beach looking for a place to sit which we did see happen. The pools were confortable and afforded some choices if one wanted to get away from children. Overall, I did have a good stay, and would go back to the Mayakoba, hoping that a stay in a suite at the beach might provide an even more enjoyable experience. We stayed for 9 nights in a signature casita and the total bill worked out to a little over $10,000. I left feeling that the Fairmont mayakoba had all the ingredients for a truly exceptional stay, but somehow our stay was not as spectacular as we would have hoped, though definitely above average. Probably for the cost and reputation of other Fairmont properties, the stay did not live up to our expectations. I'll have to see if I can talk my wife into giving it one more try. Right now she feels she would have preferred to freeze at the Plaza in NYC for the holidays, though our daughter feels we may have started a new Carribbean holiday tradition.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel but better places to stay”
Reviews.Author: Kathyks
Reviews.Content: The Fairmont Mayakoba is a beautiful resort that is very well maintained. The food was very good , the rooms are lovely and the spa was 5 star. The front desk staff and the beach staff provided poor service and had less than desirable manners. The pools were a real disappointment, the worst I have ever seen in any 4 or 5 star resort. I have been fortunate to stay at many 5 star resorts in the US and other countries and I would not recommend the Fairmont Mayakoba. You do not see the beach from your room and have to walk about 15 minutes to be on the beach. There are so many other great choices in Playa del Carmen and Cancun.

Reviews.Title: “Staff and service was fine. Tap water smells bad, added on fees.”
Reviews.Author: Hemant_Saraswat
Reviews.Content: we stayed couple of days at this fairmont. the staff was friendly and have no issues with service. The hotel is about a KM drive from the highway but we could still hear a lot of vehicle noise from our room. The accommodations are not near the beach (10-15 mins walk) so you can't just go to the beach when you want to. There is transportation (golf carts and bicycles) to take you there so not much of an issue. And their reason for not having buildings next to the beach is to protect the mangroves so I am not going to argue with that. The layout of the property does appear eco friendly - several small buildings instead of a monster complex. Meandering waterways and enough vegetation. Getting to town was not easy without a car/taxi. We didn't have a car so only option was to either take a taxi or rent a car. We ended up renting a car from the travel agency in the hotel. The tap water smells like gasoline (or something really strong) even for showers and brushing your teeth. At the time of checkout we found out that there were additional resort fees per person per night. Those were not shown at the time of reservation or check-in.

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous Oasis”
Reviews.Author: AlexTravel253
Reviews.Content: My wife and I spent 2 nights at this property on a recent trip to Cancun. We wished it was the rest of our lives. It was absolutely incredible. You are not going to believe how amazing the property is. We stayed in a Beach Area Casita Suite. The private infinity pool was mind blowing. We really enjoyed soaking in the pool, looking out over the ocean and fantasizing about living a life of luxury. The worst part about the hotel was leaving it. We had a car and paid $15 dollars a night to park, but it was great becaues Playa Del Carmen is just minutes away. The public pool areas were really spacious and pleasant. The beach in front of the hotel was great. The restaurants on site were a little pricey, but the food was delicious. I can't recommend this property enough.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Resort, Excellent Service, Very diligent security staff!!”
Reviews.Author: Stinger55
Reviews.Content: My wife and I just returned from our first stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba, Riviera Maya, Mexico. We only stayed two nights as it was the end of a six night vacation where we stayed the first four at the JW Marriott in Cancun. I wanted to specifically post since we received some excellent service from this property. I have come to expect excellent service from all Fairmont properties and employees in general when making requests, however, this one went above and beyond in my opinion and my experience has shown me that this would probably not have happened at many other hotels. I am not going to go into too much detail on restaurants as such as some previous posters have done an excellent job. We enjoyed an excellent two days of rest and relaxation at this fabulous resort. The grounds are truly impressive, I was on a NFAF promotion so we were paying $119/night and with a suite upgrade had a Signature Casita Suite overlooking the lagoon which was fabulous. Two large rooms and two full bathrooms and large balconies overlooking the water. Our second day we played at the El Camaleon course in Mayakoba which was also excellent. I found the course to be in excellent condition, the greens really ran true. I was able to scramble for an 83 from the white tees!!! Anyway, that afternoon back at the adults infinity pool, we had left our beach bag under out double lounger as we went for lunch. We had lunch at the restaurant nearby which had a terrace and we were always in full view of our lounge chairs, for the most part. I have left my ipod, wife’s ipod and her running watch, among other things in the bag. (I know what some of you are probably thinking, morons!!) Anyway, while seated for lunch we noticed some men with red badges around their neck working in a flower bed near our lounge chairs. Although I commented that I wondered what they were doing so close to our stuff, my wife suggested probably nothing and did we want to accuse workers of theft for merely doing their jobs. We didn’t want to be those type of people!! (Boy were we wrong) Anyway, after a very enjoyable lunch we returned to our area and realized our bag was no longer underneath the lounge but in the corner by the flower bed where the employees were working. After a quick check, I realized my ipod was missing, what was strange was they didn’t take my wife’s ipod. I can only assume they didn’t know what it was since it was inside a Nike running arm band. We also noticed the running watch missing. Just to be sure, I went back to the room and made sure it wasn’t in the safety deposit box, we wanted to make sure before levelling accusations. Upon my return confirming they were no in the room, I alerted the concierge at the pool. The concierge took a brief description and call hotel security. He said to go back to the pool where we were, enjoy the weather and security would be with me shortly. After taking the concierges advice, security showed up about ten minutes later and we provided a description of the items and an explanation of what happened. Security also interviewed a few people around the pool area. (there were only one or two people using this pool) The Manager of loss prevention explained that these were contract workers and that he would be investigating and would stay in touch with me until they recovered our items. I must say, all stay we talked to at the hotel that afternoon and evening were aware of what happened and expressed their apologies as they were all embarrassed of this happening at their hotel (I love the ownership at many Fairmont properties) Anyway, that night I provided the hotel with a written explanation of the events. The Manager of loss prevention called me the next morning to let me know that this would be dealt with and we would be compensated in one way or another. He explained that he was working on things and we should enjoy the last morning of our stay. He also offered us complimentary transportation to the airport if it hadn’t already been arranged. We enjoyed the morning at the pool and checked out around 11am, the Manager of loss prevention sent one of his assistant’s to meet us at check out and wanted to stress that they were working on this would hopefully have a solution shortly. We left for our 40 minute ride to CUN. After checking in at the Air Canada counter and walking to the security line up, who should come running through the doors but the Manager of loss prevention and his assistant. He first apologized for not meeting us at checkout but explained he was in a meeting with the workers and had recovered our items which he had with him and wanted to make sure we had them before we went home. The amount of travelling I do, sometimes, not very often, but sometimes things go missing, I was very pleased to see the commitment of the hotel to do everything they could to recover our items. Other moral of the story is to take our bag with us to lunch next as well. However, my thanks to the Manager of Loss Prevention and the rest of the Mayakoba staff for what I would consider going above and beyond. They really showed the pride they have in their Hotel!!

Reviews.Title: “com si com sa”
Reviews.Author: Bethaf
Reviews.Content: I just returned from a week at the Mayakoba and will largely echo back the same good and bad points already stated here, hopefully with some additional detail. Generally stated, the good is that the resort is beautiful. The food is delicious, though not cheap or widely varied. The bad is that the service is good at times, but mediocre at most. The drinks are outrageously priced and under-poured. The golf carts that run are slow, which can be annoying if you're coming back from a trip into the madness that is Mexican traffic, have many bags, or are trying to make a reservation on time. We found biking to be a better option but not ideal when you're not looking to sweat or have much to carry. Also bikes aren't always conveniently distributed. The Mayakoba could do much better on the transport across the resort. The staff is a mixed bag. There are some strong standouts but also a lot who seem to be going through the motions. Many reminded us of automatons who got in the way more than they truly provided service. We were annoyed by the batteau captain who seemed more inclined to sell Mexico and himself than to inform us about the ecosystem. Yes he did give us some insight into the canals, but he we learned more about the fish (tillapia and tarpon) in the canal from a server who was a fisherman himself. The spa is nice but not stellar. I agree with some earlier posts that the massages are excellent. I can recommend that without reservation. The facial I had was not good and defintely not worth the money. My partner enjoyed his massage as well and also liked his "feet first" treatment. The mineral pools are nice but not on a par with some of the better spas around. The fitness center is very good. I took a yoga class, which was quite adequate for what you might expect at a resort. The restaurants are beautiful, but limited. La Liguna has very good dinner entrees and a quite awesome breakfast buffet, but expect to pay $14 for a mediocre glass of wine. La Puerto was good but they disappointed me when they inquired whether we were celebrating a special occassion and failed to respond in any way to the fact that it was my s/o's 40th birthday. That was one of the less than impressive service moments. Housekeeping was adequate but inconsistent. We never recovered a coffee mug that we were missing after leaving it on the balcony one morning. Also on our final day our itinerary was thrown away--an inconvenience that cost us unnecessary time in the business center. The pools are very nice generally but too cold while we were there during the winter. This would be more tolerable if there were hot tubs, but there aren't except in the locker rooms at the spa, which you can only access if you've had a spa treatment or pay $25 for a day's access. The beach was nice, but at the time we were there had much trash on it. I realize things wash up and the resort can't totally combat that, but it still was a detraction. Our last day we were confronted with a major Eastern seaboard blizzard that seemed likely to disable our travel. Marco, the concierge, was amazingly competent, patient, and resourceful. He did much to improve our impression of the resort. If you go, try to seek him out because the others were not terribly helpful. One female concierge sent us to a pretty bad restaurant and failed to adequately explain parking conventions in Playa del Carmen even though we explicitly asked. I know the resort is high on Yatxe (sp) but despite it great ambiance, the food was pretty horrendous. Some other tips: if you rent a car, rent from Hertz because they waive the vallet parking fee. If you get a parking ticket (we did), know that they take your back license plate and be prepared to try to find the unmarked police station to retreive it. Also in town Fusion on the beach has amazing food, a great vibe, and very reasonable prices. Out of PdC, we enjoyed Puetro Aventura for it's low stress, good value environment. A special standout was Gringo Daves. They cooked our freshly caught fish for free and charged us only $5 for a wide array of sauces on our fish, rice, and great grilled veggies. Lastly don't fall for the insurance the rental cars try to railrod you into and if you do rent from Hertz, don't bother with the guys/girls who try to shanghai you with claims of disounts, free tickets and food, etc. It may be legit offers, but we learned it's a time share and chose not to increase our aggravation with the Mexican hussle on vacation.

Reviews.Title: “Very Nice, and Very Quite”
Reviews.Author: MMRDAR5
Reviews.Content: • We just returned for a week at the property, we all enjoyed ourselves; however, the hotel was not very busy, and at times the kids were looking for what to do. The design of the property is a bit atypical from other beach reports. The hotel is comprised of small casitas, and you need to take a golf cart to get around. Our kids LOVED the golf carts; in fact they were a highlight of the day. The staff was great, and very accommodating ting. My only complaint was with the menus. The choices seemed to become boring very quickly. And there were no specials. There is only one outlet open for breakfast, and the same location -- La Laguna, is the only truly kid friendly venue. Three meals a day at the location can get old real fast. You can venture to Playa Del Carmen for more variety, however, it’s a 20 minute taxi ride. Mayakoba, is not Cancun, and you cannot walk from your hotel to a "strip" with a ton of food choices. The beach is beautiful, and the main pool (near La Laguna) has a water slide the kids loved. I rained one day during our stay, and both the concierge, and the tour office (independent of the hotel) were at a loss to make suggestions of what to do with the kids. Don’t get me wrong, the place is great, and I would recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “unique and plesant, but not enough to return”
Reviews.Author: RPH3
Reviews.Content: Wife, 21 year old son and I had a very good Thanksgiving - were pleased with the service. Marco the Concierge was very good. Email before arrival secured private transport from airport fo $75 for all of us vs other reviews suggesting $100 for cab. Also helped with diving and ferry schedule to Cozumel (Give Cozumel 2 hours max as its the old aggressive t shirt hussle - vs more laid back,classier and fun in Playa). Housekeeping was very good. Another review suggested walking down the beach for lunch and we found this a great addition to the limited food options at the hotel. Spa is over the top, one of the best massages of my life ($129 plus automatic 15%). Didn't golf, but the course looked great. One tip: We had the driver stop at a 7-11 on the way to stock up on beer/drinks/snakes for our own happy hour. Fridge in room made thiseasy.

Reviews.Title: “IBM Forum in Cancun”
Reviews.Author: CesarMaciel
Reviews.Content: Excellent hotel, nice amenities. Food and beverages are very expensive, so bring your own beer ;-)

Reviews.Title: “Very relaxing and unique setting...”
Reviews.Author: Ryder013
Reviews.Content: My 7 month pregnant wife and I recently spent a week at the Fairmont Mayakoba for our two year anniversary. We've been to some pretty amazing resorts in the past and the Fairmont Mayakoba was right up there with the best. The property is massive and the layout a little confusing - but apparently it was designed not to interfere with the existing ecosystem. That resulted in a unique jungle-like setting with lots of waterways and wildlife right at your front door. The resort was pretty empty and it rained for the first few days thanks to Hurricane Ida (and cloudy the rest of the time) but that didn't bother us too much given how nice our room was! ROOMS - We stayed in one of the Signature Casitas (Coral Suite - Room 644) which overlooked the mangroves. The suite was absolutely massive at around 1,000 square feet. The bathrooms (yes, plural) were very cool with glass walls that gave you the feeling of showering outside. Don't worry though. You're surrounded by jungle so no one can see in. 24 hour room service with a big menu is always nice too... SERVICE - The service was fantastic. Can't think of anything negative to say! Everyone seemed to know it was our 2 year anniversary despite only mentioning it to one staff member! There was the occasional error on our dinner bills but they were fixed immediately. Nothing to worry about. CLEANLINESS - The entire resort was spotless. Our suite was cleaned 3x a day - no issues with house keeping. We like new things and this resort was only a few years old. Everything was brand new. BEACH - The beach was awesome but a 15 minute walk from the main resort, unless you were lucky enough to get a suite right on the beach. Luckily golf carts came by every 5 minutes to take you back and forth. A great restaurant (Las Brisas) and pool right on the beach made the trip worth it. They even brought us snacks (fruit cups) and cucumber eye patches while relaxing on the beach. FOOD - The food was absolutely amazing 10/10. Best we've ever had. It is expensive but the portions are big so you get your money's worth. My wife is a vegetarian and thought there would be nothing for her to eat, but she was blown away. Las Brisas has the best atmosphere and view of the beach but El Puerto (in the main building) had the best food. We stocked up on drinks and snacks at the cafe located at the main pool. Be sure to try the Chocolate Chip muffins ;) SPA - The spa was first-class. My wife went back for a second maternity massage. Worth every penny. ENTERTAINMENT - Unfortunately there wasn't any. During dinner, there was always live music, which was great, but not the "shows" that other resorts typically have. We were just there to relax, so we really didn't care about the lack of entertainment. The resort was pretty empty but we didn't mind. We took a one-hour private boat tour around the resort one morning which was really fun. The "Venice of the Caribbean"... VALUE - Definitely a 5+ star resort. If you're looking to relax, the Fairmont Mayakoba is the place for you. We would definitely recommend for a Honeymoon but not so much for a large group looking to party. Can't wait to go back!

Reviews.Title: “Relaxing”
Reviews.Author: knanasi
Reviews.Content: I chose the Fairmont Mayakoba for a beach getaway with my three daughters. This was our second trip. We stayed in the deluxe casita, which was closer to the beach and also afforded more privacy. The rooms were extremely large, with two queen beds and a fridge that could be stocked with items purchased on-site, or with supplies you bring with you. The bathroom was also very large, with a huge soaking tub that looks out onto a garden area (if you are on the ground floor). The view from the tub in the upstairs rooms is only of a wooden screen, but the light comes in and it is also quite nice. The opposite end of the room opens via sliding door to a patio or balcony. It is wonderful to sit there in the morning and listen to the many exotic birds. The view from the Deluxe Casita is of the jungle, which some people have criticized, but I found it wonderfully secluded and relaxing. The room is also equipped with electric kettle and Bodin coffee maker as well as a teapot. The property is quite spread out, and you get around by golfcart or bicycles. There are several pools, including an adults only pool. My only criticism of the pools is that the beachside pool is rather small, and there are no hot tubs at any of the pools (there is a hot tub in the spa facility, but you must have booked a treatment that day to have access. The restaurants are OK, fairly expensive. The beachside burgers, guacamole, etc are fine. Poolside drinks are great-try the Miami Vice and add a little extra rum-delicious! The spa and fitness center are very good. I have been back twice and will go again next year.

Reviews.Title: “Absolutely wonderful...”
Reviews.Author: txcowgirly
Reviews.Content: Great hotel. Staff was extremely attentive but not hovering. Pool area and beach was equally great. Room was to die for, with large closets, huge shower, jacuzzi tub. Had breakfast on the balcony every morning, slept with the french doors open every night to the sounds of birds and rain in the trees. Golf course was amazing. Short taxi-ride into the village of Playa for dinner and live music one evening, but there was really no reason to leave the resort. Have to put this place at the very top of the list for cleanliness, comfort, staff, scenery, food, drinks.....everything.

Reviews.Title: “It doesn't get much better than this!”
Reviews.Author: sungal7
Reviews.Content: This hotel is absolutely amazing! We stayed in one of the oceanfront villas with our own infinity pool on the beach. The service is fantastic. The food is wonderful. And you can't get a better setting!

Reviews.Title: “World-class resort at recession prices.”
Reviews.Author: RamblinDad
Reviews.Content: Lovely, though like other reviewers I'd be more critical if I were paying rack rates ($400+). We got a fire-sale rate of $155 (plus resort fees and taxes, it was $209 all-in) for the deluxe casita. Some might not like waiting for the (frequent) golf carts to take you to the pools, the beach, the restaurants -- there are bicycles, but we couldn't use them with our little ones, and walking would take awhile, the grounds are extensive -- but the kids loved the "taxis" and you got used to it. Only 3 restaurants (plus a lounge and cafe), so dining choices are limited for a stay of more than the 3 days we were there, especially if one of the restaurants is closed for a private event -- several business groups file through here, though they were small, a few dozen people, so it didn't feel like a "conference center" hotel. You can dine at the restaurants at the neighboring resorts, though we decided to stick with the Fairmont restaurants after we learned that kids (under 6? I think?) eat free! The surf is stronger at this beach than at Mamita's in Playa, where we had spent a week at a condo just prior to this resort, so our little ones preferred the pools. One nice thing about the pools is a series of alcoves (think railroad ties) that are quite private, even while being part of the big pool. Great water slide; kids club is just aiight. Rooms are beautiful and very private, surrounded by the forest: it feels like you're in your own cabana, even though the casitas share walls like townhouses. A nice change of pace from Cancun. Definitely join the Fairmont Presidents' Club before going; you'll get free local calls and internet.

Reviews.Title: “Heaven!”
Reviews.Author: vacationguru14
Reviews.Content: This place is amazing and the service is EXCELLENT. I would highly recommend this resort!

Reviews.Title: “The ultimate!!!”
Reviews.Author: mlogab
Reviews.Content: We just came back two weeks ago from what we will call the ultimate vacation... This resort is second to none...Not only is it set on the most beautiful location it offers superior accomodation and settings... From the moment we got to the hotel, where we were greeted with a fresh cold towel and a tropical drink to the moment we left, we were treated like the most valued clients ever... When I say the site is exceptional, pictures and video available on the Fairmont website are exactly what you get... Service is impeccable from the rooms to frontdesk to pools , beaches and restaurants... We ate every morning and night at The Laguna, which offers enough variety but exceptional quality for the price you pay...I can not rave enough about the service and food...Travelling with 2 young ones and a teenager sometimes is difficult to please everyone...Both my wife and I could enjoy great food while the kids would feast on anything from the3 kids menu or just enjoy a fabulous Laguna burger. We had exceptional service from the hostesses Viridiana and Aliser, who would always welcome us with huge smiles and hugs for our two daughters, while servers Fabiola,Jose, Alfonso, Iran and others were just so attentive its was unbelievable. Always would they refer to us by our last name while they would use our kids name when talking to them...Marco the chef is awesome and will prpare food that will blow you away...Difficult to find better in this price range ( kids 7$, adults between 18 and 30$) The beach though far from the casitas we were in, were easy to access with the electrical carts that travel the resort at every moment. Never would you have to wait more than 5 minutes to get from one place to the other. Having walked south on the beach and having seen other locations, the Fairmont offers BY FAR the nicest strand of beach with crisp turquoise and blue water ( there are some small rocks for which you have to be careful and find the right spot in the water). Rooms are huge and beautifully decorated with enormous washrooms. It is very elegant and pleasing to the eye. Travelling a lot and staying in hotels all the time, much to my astonishment I must say that the AC was exceptionnally efficient as I did not suffer from the usual dryness or even clogged nose... There are numerous pools ( a couple infinity ones) around the resort and all were clean and beautiful..The kids especially enjoyed the one with the slide.. Wy wife also treated herself to a morning at the spa and enjoyed every moment! All in all, an outstanding stay with 7 days of beautiful weather in a resort that is worth every penny of it! Muchas gracias per todo!

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel and great price”
Reviews.Author: traveling_mom_dc
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Fairmont hotel for a summer break with the kids. The resort is beautiful, the staff is very friendly and the rooms are beautiful. I have stayed in 5 star resorts around the world and this resort measures up to the best at a fraction of the price. The food at Las Brisas is delicious, as was the breakfast buffet. We upgraded to a casita suite which was one of the nicest rooms I have stayed in with a beautiful bathroom. The hotel is near enough, yet far enough from Cancun; near enough to use the great airport, far enough to allow serenity. Also, we went to Playa del Carmen for dinner several nights and was very impressed. Not once did I feel uncomfortable, parking was easy, shopping was great, restaurants were great, and the prices were reasonable. I cannot stress that this was a stress free trip at a 5 star resort for a very reasonable price. Honestly, no complaints, trust me I would post the complaints if there were any!

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous & isolated . . .”
Reviews.Author: team_tour
Reviews.Content: This was my first time in Mexico, so I didn't have any expectations. The security and architecture of the entrance to the hotel was very impressive. It makes you feel like a VIP everytime you drive up. The lobby was beautiful. The staff was extremely attentive from the time you get there until the time you leave. Without asking, when we checked in, we were given a free upgrade to a casita. However, when we got there, it was a casita on the lower level that had a private porch with a view of trees and the sidewalk. We decided to ask for an upgrade to an upper level casita. They gave us the option to upgrade to an upper level casita on the lagoon for $50USD. When we got to the new room, it was an upper level casita on the lagoon, but half of the lagoon view was blocked by trees growing out of the lagoon. As far as we can see, no other casita had their lagoon view half blocked by shrubs. Since we were tired and exhausted at this point, we decided to stay. The room was beautiful and felt luxurious in a rustic way. The bathroom was amazing! It had double sinks, a large soaking tube, a separate standing shower with a "rainfall" shower head and a hand held sprayer, a water closet, and marble tiling throughout. When we went to the cafe by the pool to grab something to eat, we found the food was extremely expensive. Their pre-made gourmet sandwiches were more than $9USD! My husband got one of those sandwiches and I decided to get pre-made a ceasar salad. The girl brought it the register, then pickup the container with the dressing said something to her coworker. They said something back and forth in spanish, and she took it to the back. Ten minutes later, she came back with a bigger container, with a dressing that was white. The original dressing was yellow, which is the correct color for a ceasar dressing, considering the main ingredient is egg yolk. She placed it in our bag and flashed us a huge smile. Needless to say, I was AFRAID to eat the dressing and we never went back to the cafe. The maid service comes twice a day. Once in the morning and once at night to refresh the room. The first time the maid came after we settled in, the bathtub and shower had an unbearable mildew/mold smell. The glass cups on the night stand also had a very strong moldy smell. We also found a small lizard in the water closet, which we tried to catch with a cup so that we could set it free, unfortunately it was too quick. Poor guy! The beach is unbelievable! The sand is white and soft. The water is light turquoise green and very warm. It rivals the beaches in Tahiti. Relaxing under the shade from the umbrella, staring out at the white sand and beautiful water, and being served pina coladas by an outstanding server...we felt like we were in paradise. We did rent a car so we were able to come and go as we pleased. Since the hotel is not in walking in distance of any restaurants, shops, or activities, I believe we would’ve felt too isolated if we didn’t have a car. Even though the beach is gorgeous, we’re too active to just relax on the beach several days in a row. Also like other reviewers, we believe that the food is good but it would be very financially draining to eat most of your meals there. The avg price for an entrée is $15USD. For each order, there is an additional $5USD delivery charge, 10% government tax, and 15% gratuity added. Just so that you can gauge, a really good made-to-order taco at a local restaurant around Playa del Carmen is $6 peso or $0.50 USD. Even at this price, we were still getting ripped off! If you went to the local modern (very nice) supermarket and bought gourmet deli smoked turkey (the best brand that you could buy), gourmet grueyere cheese, apples, bananas, gourmet pasteries, Rambutan (exotic fruit), a bottle of moderate French wine, and a baguette, it would cost $19USD. Bottom line, make sure you rent a car, rest assure that there are plenty of great food and shopping options a few miles away in Playa del Carmen, and BARGAIN. If you don’t bargain, you will end up shelling out as much as if you went to the Hamptons or Beverly Hills. Yes, they are that aggressive there!

Reviews.Title: “Perfect resort for honeymooners – basically anyone who wants to spend a lot of time alone in a room or on the beach”
Reviews.Author: ElenaAP
Reviews.Content: The resort is absolutely gorgeous, and you couldn’t ask for better staff. Food and drinks were delicious. Beds were comfortable, décor impeccable. The resort is very secluded and insulated – so you should feel safe despite its eerie isolation (I went with a large convention, but the grounds still felt quite empty). After just three days, I got a bad case of island fever (I recommend renting a car because it is not easy to get on and off the property otherwise). There is no place else to eat, no where to go without leaving the complex. The room service menu is limited and pricey – so I tired quickly of my options. The beach was relatively close, but I took the Cushman (not wanting to walk in the heat). The villas all look the same, so I managed to get lost frequently (even with a map, I had a difficult time navigating). The Cushmans run throughout the day, but they are unreliable. I tried calling to schedule pick-ups, but I was told to go outside and wait. One last piece of advice, you can fly into both Cancun and Cozumel to get to Riviera Maya. Cozumel was a cheaper flight for me, but I didn’t realize I would have to take a very bumpy, lengthy ferry to the mainland (I don’t get seasick easily, but I was green after this ferry ride). Gorgeous and luxurious place, just not really suited to my personal preference. I’d rate it 5 / 5 if it weren’t for the limited dining, creepy isolation and confusing layout.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing!”
Reviews.Author: jojoOhio
Reviews.Content: We had read the reviews prior to booking on hotels website, so we knew what to expect; Impeccable service! We were greeted by name with a scented cool towel and tropical drink.We received a double upgrade upon check-in. Our room was amazing! We were canal front. We had complete privacy at all times, even with the doors open to our balcony. The tropical garden outside our bath was incredible. Great amenities! Robes, upscale toiletries, safe, ipod bose radio, flat screeen tv. Room was stocked with bottled water twice daily. Absolutely the best bathroom ever! The jungle infinity pool was very restful. We had it to ourselves most of the time. Never had trouble getting a chaise at the beach or at the beachfront pool. It was a long way to the beach but we never had to wait more than a couple of minutes for a ride. The decor was amazing. Live music in lobby every night. Very romantic! We rented a car and drove from the airpoirt. Couldn't have been easier. Drove into town most evenings for dinner. An easy 5-10 minute drive. Great food. Good prices.Never had trouble finding parkng. Never felt safer. We loved the Fairmont and can't wait to go back!

Reviews.Title: “A magic oasis!”
Reviews.Author: Truttyy
Reviews.Content: Everything about this place is excellent! It is exclusive, chic and service is awesome.Only some things you need to know: VALET PARKING: You do need a car, unless you plan to stay here the whole vacation. Rent a car with HERTZ and they do not charge for valet parking. LOCATION: It is only about 10 min. from Playa del Carmen, however the hotel has bar and restaurants available. It is huge but they have bikes and golfcars always available. PRICES: Consider being in the US. As here all prices are in US and you pay as much or more as if you were in the States. BEACH: AMAZING! NATURE: You are basically in the middle of the jungle, so if nature is not for you... look somewhere else. KIDS: I read reviews about lots of kids but did not see them... maybe because I didn't go to the kids pool. So I think that as long as you stay away from it, you will be ok. RELAX: ABSOLUTELY! SIZE: The rooms are huge and the bathrooms are great! DRINKS: Margaritas are great, I hated piña coladas, but the ones here are EXTREMELY GOOD!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful resort, limited options”
Reviews.Author: vancouver_petunia
Reviews.Content: Stayed at this resort for a corporate convention. There were about 300 of us there and I was part of the planning team for the event. From an event planning standpoint, the hotel did an outstanding job of facilitating our event, providing 3rd party services, solving problems, dealing with our guests, etc. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this team for an event. The hotel is simply beautiful; the grounds are amazing. The grounds are also huge and if you are not fortunate enough to be able to afford the casitas near the beach, you are a good distance from the water. It's not a huge problem, as the hotel has plenty of transportation options -- golf carts, bicycles, boats, etc. But most guests are not facing the water or walking out onto the beach from their rooms. The beach is a bit small, but gorgeous. The pools are lovely and intertwined throughout the grounds. That said, it didn't seem like there were that many pools or that the pools themselves were that large (one was very big, but the others quite small). There are 3 restaurants plus a cafe & lobby bar on site. Although the food was generally very good, service could be slow at peak times. Also, with only 3 restaurants on site, the lack of variety over the course of a week did get tiring. As the hotel is a good distance from the town of Playa del Carmen, we did not take the opportunity to go into town very often (we were often working evenings), so could not break up the restaurant monotony. I probably personally would not stay at this hotel again. It is out of my personal budget, for one. But even if it was within my budget, I felt the hotel didn't offer enough options for restaurants, pools, beaches and activities. But lying on a beach for a week and doing nothing is not my style. If you want to be pampered at a beautiful, relaxing resort, this might be the place for you.

Reviews.Title: “Great on many levels!”
Reviews.Author: vimatravel
Reviews.Content: Ive visited Cancun at least a dozen times allways staying ay the Ritz Carlton once at Le Meridian and have been curious about the " Riviera Maya " The Fairmont was a perfect choice! Dont bother with the poor reviews my guess is they were based on very limited travel expieriece especially in the luxury category. The service was spot on... friendly genuine and relaxed. The accomidations were lovley we stayed in a casita with a large balcony great room elegent and spacious. The food was good not great but the grouper at Las Brisas was excellent I had it 3X. The Spa was wonderful one of the best massages I ever had. I look forward to my next visit!

Reviews.Title: “Perfect in every way”
Reviews.Author: pocketcathy
Reviews.Content: This was the best trip of my life. The hotel is beautiful, the staff is friendly (they knew our names by our first evening there), the restaurants are amazing (lobster tails as big as my head -- no lies!), the spa is incredible (I recommend the massage for couples -- divine), the proximity to sites is good. We used the travel agency within the hotel to schedule our day trip to Chichen Itza, which was a seamless trip -- a rarity in Latin America! We saw all kinds of wildlife around the resort itself, especially the canal system. The resort has four ways to get around: walking, biking, golf carts, or boats. Each way is lovely. I can't wait to stay here again. I measure all my vacations against my time at the Mayakoba. It was a perfect week.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect combination: Fun location, unbelievably great service”
Reviews.Author: wishyouwerehere44
Reviews.Content: This year's family vacation (mom, dad & 8 year-old) was perfect in every way. First, we got very reasonable rates at this time of year (summer is Cancun's slow season) and due to the swine-flu & economic downturn, flights were relatively cheap too. The Mayakoba is about 30 mins. south of the airport, and 15 mins. north of Playa del Carmen. Renting a car is essential, as there are so many actives (snorkeling at Xel-Ha, Mayan ruins at Tulum & Chichen Itza, dining off-site in Cancun or Playa del Carmen) all require driving. Even renting a car was extremely cheap ($75 for a week's rental not counting insurance). We've stayed at five star hotels throughout the world and already know that Mexican service/hospitality is arguably the best in general. The staff at the Fairmont were the best of the best. We ate most meals at the hotel's three restaurants. La Laguana is for breakfast and casual dinner. Las Brisas is on the beach and higher end, fusion. We only ate at Las Brisas once for dinner and it was adequate but nothing special. One of the hotel's finest assets is the El Puerto restaurant and the waiter named Felipe. I can say unequivocally that he is the best waiter we've ever had. We ended up eating here three times and he remembered what we ordered at previous meals and made recommendations based upon our personal tastes. We celebrated our wedding anniversary here one night and it was perfect: unbelievable service, beautiful setting on the patio overlooking the water on a cool night and very tasty food that pleased our entire party. The layout of the hotel is a bit unusual. The resort is spread over a wide area and taking carts (driven by hotel staff) is necessary to get from the lobby to rooms, to restaurants and to the beach or pools. While this seems unorthodox, it works well and you never have to wait long for a cart to come take you where you want to go. The payoff is that privacy is enhanced and you never get the sense of being in a crowd. The first few nights we stayed in a deluxe room in the 500s which was very nice. Through the Fairmont's presidents club we got a free suite upgrade for the last 5 nights and we were given a beach-front 1 bed-room cabana. (!) Easily the nicest room we've ever stayed in. Right on the beach with a private pool, ample space and wonderful in every way. The stay would have been terrific even without the suite upgrade, but this was unbelievable. We will be going back and recommending to everyone.

Reviews.Title: “Unbelievable stay”
Reviews.Author: canuck225
Reviews.Content: I can't say enough good things about the service, staff, and the resort itself and am shocked that Fairmont Mayakoba isn't one of the top rated resorts in the Riviera Maya area on Tripadvisor. I had contacted reservations and the concierge by email prior to arrival and they promptly took care of all my requests. On arrival, we were shocked to receive the ultimate in upgrades to the El Cameleon presidential suite on the beach. The suite was huge and had a 800 square foot private terrace with a view of and access to the beach. We had activities planned in the Riviera Maya area but cancelled them so we could spend more time enjoying the suite. The manager at Las Brisas restaurant allowed us to stay on the patio after close on our first night and continued bar service. And the following day, Las Brisas was closed for dinner (due to low occupancy, around 20%) but the staff arranged a table beachside for us. It was just one example how the staff went that extra step to make our stay memorable. We also dined at Casa Del Lago at Rosewood during our stay (the Fairmont provided free transportation) which was very nice. Previous posters have complained about the high prices for dining at Mayakoba but I actually found it to be quite reasonably priced for a 4/5 star resort. To address another common complaint, yes most of the rooms are a bit of a walk from the beach. But with any amount of research, people should have been aware of this before booking. We found the bike transportation a fun way to get around and we never had to wait long for a golf cart. And finally, I've read complaints about the $25 a day 'resort fee' charge. This is actually a minor charge in comparison to the additional 10-15% service charge that other resorts such as Rosewood, Mandarin Oriental, and Maroma add onto ALL services. The gym and the spa are nice but the massage I received was just average. I wouldn't recommend the boat tour on the lagoon either. The beach is gorgeous and was not crowded at all when we were there. The ocean is rocky in a couple places but is fine as you move away from the shore. There was a nice breeze in the evenings which kept the mosquitoes away (I didn't see one during my stay). If you're looking for a quiet, relaxing place to stay in the Riviera Maya area, I would highly recommend checking out the Fairmont Mayakoba. We had the time of our lives and were treated like royalty during our stay and will definitely return in the future.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic!”
Reviews.Author: jenniferp_nyc
Reviews.Content: Let me start by saying that this is one of the best hotel experiences I've had in recent memory. Fantastic experience! The Fairmont Mayakoba is located on the Yucatan's Mayan Riviera near Playa del Carmen. The Mayakoba property is quite large and absolutely stunning and it's impressive that such a large place with so many outbuildings (the "casitas" that make up the accommodations) was given such care to fit in to its beautiful natural surroundings of mangrove forest and water. And the gorgeously designed open-air lobby building with its spectacular views of the property and the ocean defies description. Simply beautiful. The property is criscrossed by canals, which can be used to ferry guests around the property (don't miss the 8am boat trip around the property. We saw crocodiles, storks, turtles and iguanas on that trip alone.) Guests can also move about the property on bicycles that are provided or simply walk the lovely walkways to get to the restaurants, spa, pools or beach. There are also golf carts that will pick you up at many locations every five minutes and drive you to your destination. The beach is a 10-minute walk from the main property and is clean, beautiful and well-attended. There's a pool and restaurant right above the beach, so you could spend the entire day there. Back on the main property, there are a number of other pools, including the stunning infinity pool (adults only) that overlooks a large canal populated with cormorants and other sea birds. We spent most of our trip parked there, on their luxurious padded beach chaises. There are three main restaurants on the property, varied in their menus and all good quality, if pricey. There's also a small cafe that serves coffee and sandwiches and supplies some grocery items. We opted to take a taxi to Walmart in Playa del Carmen our first night (thanks to a tip from a TripAdvisor reviewer) and stocked up on water and groceries, saving a lot of money we would have spent at the restaurants. The resort is not within walking distance of any other restaurants or shops, so you either eat at the hotel restaurants, take a taxi to a restaurant at Playa del Carmen nearby or fill your room fridge with groceries. The rooms are large and comfortable and beautifully furnished and all have balconies overlooking pools or canals (on our last night while we sat drinking wine on our balcony, a 6-foot crocodile leisurely swam by in the canal below us.) There doesn't seem to be a bad view anywhere on the property. And because the casitas are nestled into the large property, you have a great deal of privacy and a sense that you're the only guests at the resort. As great as all of these things were, the real reason to stay at the Mayakoba is for the service. I have never stayed anywhere before where the staff was as gracious, accommodating, courteous and professional. I have no idea what kind of training they go through, but whatever it is, the Fairmont is doing it right. I've had wonderful service at the Fairmont in Bermuda and in San Jose, CA, but this just exceeded all our expectations. They were the nicest, friendliest staff who never questioned a request from us and accommodated us as efficiently and quickly as they could every time. We were treated like special guests by everyone there, something so often missing in hotel experiences. One note: the Mayakoba charges $15/US/day per guest for service. That means that you don't have to tip every person who helps you with something during the trip. Given how much assistance you get there (golf cart drivers, bellmen, cleaning staff, beach/pool staff, etc.) this was great, because we didn't have to constantly remember to carry small bills and tip each person separately. It made the whole trip more relaxing. Loved it and would go back in a heartbeat. I highly recommend the Mayakoba for your next trip to Mexico!! -Jennifer

Reviews.Title: “Unbelievable”
Reviews.Author: hobbiezm
Reviews.Content: Upon my return from Fairmont Maykoba, I happened to read the review from the earlier post dated Memorial Day 2009; I couldn't have written it better myself. We had the same lavish treatment, had a double room upgrade, and well and truly were treated like royalty without ever being made to feel like we paid for it. From Hugo greeting us upon arrival, to Hyde coming out personally to greet my husband and I, the trip was wonderful; on a side note, one should note that if you are fairly young, going with friends, the resort is slightly isolated which was perfect for my husband and I celebrating our 3 year anniversary. Also, the food is quite expensive; however the quality was remarkable. I advise anyone to go to the fairmont Mayakoba, and enjoy the trip of a lifetime. I felt it was magical for the main reason alone... the people of the resort and Mexico were truly warm, and helpful.

Reviews.Title: “May-Amazing: A Detailed Review”
Reviews.Author: jmbatl
Reviews.Content: (4.5 stars.) I spend almost 100 nights in hotel rooms each year and only rarely post reviews on Tripadvisor. Only occasionally do I feel my insights can add to the already lengthy body of information available here on virtually any hotel or resort worldwide. However, I knew I would post a review of the Fairmont Mayakoba even before I arrived there. Why? Well, it seemed to me that there were far too few detailed reviews of this hotel among the dozens of pages of submissions. Most reviewers described the hotel as 'outstanding' or 'disappointing' without providing the kind of information that can really be of help to those planning a stay here. For that reason, I will go into quite a bit of detail on what we experienced during our stay at the Fairmont over Memorial Day weekend. Our trip to Riviera Maya was planned last minute - about a week in advance. It came as no surprise that Mexico was by far the cheapest destination where one could reasonably spend a long weekend. Thank you swine flu. Our rate at the Fairmont Mayakoba was unreal. We paid less than half of discounted low season rates. I feel it's important to note this in a hotel review, because I truly believe the rate one pays has a huge impact on their perception of a resort, particularly when it comes to service. According to one of the many staff members we encountered during our stay, occupancy rates for the weekend we were there were around 20 percent. This is also of note, as our experience may have been different at 100 percent occupancy or even 50 percent occupancy. We enjoy staying at resorts around the world during their 'low seasons' and enjoy the peace and extra attention that comes with staying at a sparsely populated property. Arrival: We arrived by rental car from Cancun airport after an approximately 35 minute drive. The Fairmont is one of four resorts (one is currently under construction) in the Mayakoba Development. It is also the largest and the least expensive. The other resorts currently in operation in Mayakoba -- Rosewood and Banyan Tree -- both have only about 100 rooms and rates in the $1,000 per night range. The Mandarin Oriental is adjacent to Mayakoba but outside the development. Anyone entering Mayakoba must clear a security checkpoint. From there, it's a short drive along winding stone and concrete roads to the Fairmont reception. There are lighted signs to guide you, but the text is a bit small. Reception/Check-In: From the moment we emerged from our vehicle, we were greeted by name. Presumably, the security guard at the front notified the hotel staff we were enroute. We were presented with cool towels car side. Our bags were literally whisked away. By the time I got around to the trunk, they were gone. At the entrance to the expansive, open air lobby, we were presented with a non-alcoholic welcome drink on a tray. It was fruity and refreshing. Again, at each step along the way, we were greeted by name. Given our ultra-cheap rate, I was a bit concerned that we would be assigned the most basic room. In fact, we were told by the front desk clerk that we were upgraded to a 'casita.' After taking care of the paperwork, we were introduced to Hugo, who walked us to a balcony overlooking the entire resort and briefly described the layout. Hugo then escorted us to a golf cart and drove us to our second-level casita near the heart of the property. Once we arrived at our room, he gave us a brief tour of the room and explained how to work the AC, lights, ceiling fan, etc. As Hugo was leaving, our bags arrived, and the bellman placed them directly in the closets. Room: Our casita was spacious and thoughtfully designed. A king bed, sitting chair, and desk furnished the main room, along with a credenza with drawers, cabinets, a refrigerator and a flat panel LCD TV. The bed was very pleasant and on par with a five-star resort. I can see how some might complain about firmness, but it didn't bother me at all. High speed internet access was hard wired and worked well (at US$20 per day, but complimentary for Presidents Club members, which is a great deal).Three phones, one cordless. An awesome Bose sound system with an auxiliary jack for iPods or Mp3 players (not a dock, you actually need your own mini jack to mini jack cord to make this work). Air conditioner was efficient and kept the room very cool. There was also a variable-speed ceiling fan above the bed. A short hallway led to the bathroom with full size closets on either side. This was great, as my girlfriend and I each had a place to store our clothes. There was a safe in one closet big enough to fit my laptop computer, although I had to angle it to get it inside. The bathroom, as mentioned by others, was truly remarkable. It included a double vanity (very large with tons of counter space), a deep soaking tub (no jets), a water closet, and an oversized shower with a bench and a rain-type faucet on the ceiling, in addition to a handheld faucet. The complimentary shampoo, conditioner, shower gel, soap were Miller-Harris, very high end. The most impressive feature were the huge windows above the bath and in the shower. A wood screen outside maintains privacy while housing a small stone garden and allowing bathers a view of the sky. In the morning, the warm sun streamed into the shower. At night, we could see the stars while soaking in the tub. The floors were solid surface throughout (not tile, maybe polished limestone?). On the opposite side of the room, outside sliding glass doors, was a large wooden lanai with a small seating area of two comfortable chairs and end table. View/Balcony: Very few (and only the most expensive) rooms have ocean views. This is the case for the Rosewood and the Mandarin Oriental, as well. All of the newer resorts in this stretch of Riviera Maya were required to maintain much of the original mangroves and foliage. The mangroves also protect the resorts from hurricanes. These are not large buildings on an ocean like you see in Cancun. These are sprawling resorts with rooms nestled in mangroves or on lagoons. Know this going in. If you're looking for an ocean view, be prepared to pay $1000/night for an oceanfront villa (with private pool), or look elsewhere. Our room overlooked a thatch of thick trees. On the second level, we were almost at the tree tops. The trees provided an exceptional amount of privacy. We virtually could not be seen by anyone else when sitting on our balcony. We also enjoyed spotting colorful birds and iguanas in the trees. Bugs were, for the most part, only a problem at dusk. I would recommend bringing and using insect repellent if you want to sit outside at dusk. Otherwise, our balcony was very comfortable and, again, very private, and we enjoyed spending much time there. Other casitas have lagoon views. The main hotel building has a resort view. Property: Because the resort is sprawling, getting around can be a challenge (or part of the adventure, depending on how you look at it). From our casita, we could easily walk to the lobby, central pools, and main hotel restaurant. The beach (with the best pool and restaurant) is about 3/4th of a mile down a concrete path that winds through mangroves and over lagoons.
