If you don't want to walk, you have two options: you can pick up one of a number of bikes scattered around the property (I'd say we could easily find at least two bikes 75 percent of the time we looked for them), or you can wait for one of many golf cart shuttles that circle the property. We never waited more than two or three minutes for a golf cart. There are covered areas near each casita where you can phone for one, but we never waited long enough to do this. Let me be clear, for us -- two young people who like adventure and activity -- getting around the property was never a problem and actually provided a number of joyful moments. Pool: There are five pools on the property: a small pool near the resort building, a kids' pool near the kid activity center, a sprawling pool with fountains and bridges, a slide and swim up bar in the center of the property, an adults only, infinity pool overlooking a lagoon, and the oceanfront pool, also infinity, on the beach. We spent our entire weekend at the beach pool. It was never overcrowded. We would arrive around late morning or midday and have our pick of chairs. That said, it is a relatively small pool, and, as it's the most popular, I can imagine it would be difficult to secure a good spot when occupancy levels are higher. All the pools were luxurious and looked wonderful, but we wanted to be able to look out at the ocean while we swam and sunbathed. That said, I probably would have been just as happy at the adult pool. Attendants handle dressing the lounge chairs in towels and provide a rolled towel for a pillow, which we thought was great. A waiter makes the rounds fairly frequently taking drink and food orders -- not as frequently as at some resorts I've been to, but frequently enough to be of service. Our second day poolside, cucumber slices and ice pops were handed out complimentary. Spa/Fitness: We toured the spa and it looked magnificent. We didn't end up booking procedures because it was fairly pricey (US$129-US$149 for 60 minute massage, although they presented us with a $25 gift certificate at check in) and we were just as happy spending our time by the pool. I won't go into much detail about the spa, but one of the best and most unusual features seemed to be the co-ed, rooftop pool and hot tub, which would be a great place to spend time with a loved one after a treatment. The fitness center was well equipped with treadmills, elliptical machines, and stationary bikes. Each machine had a personal TV. Towels and bottled water were placed at each machine by an attendant. There were also the requisite compliment of free weights and weight machines. There are two or three fitness classes each day that are complimentary. There is a US$10 charge per person, per day to use the fitness center. The charge is waived, though, for Presidents Club members. It is absolutely free to join the Presidents Club, and pays off in many ways, including free internet. This should be your first priority after booking a reservation at any Fairmont. Food: Much has been said about the food at Fairmont Mayakoba, positive and negative. But, again, it seemed to me that few shared the kind of detail that would be really helpful -- like exactly HOW expensive the food is. Bottom line, the prices are on par with a five-star resort, maybe a bit cheaper thanks to the Peso. If you stay at a five-star resort, you must expect the food and drinks to be pricey. There are plenty of all-inclusives in this area (and nice ones), if that's what you're looking for. The night we arrived, we dined at Las Brisas, one of two AAA four diamond restaurants on property. (The other AAA four diamond, El Puerto, was closed for the week due to the low occupancy rates. This was a disappointment, but understandable.) Even though our reservation at Las Brisas was at 10p, making us the last couple to dine, the service was absolutely impeccable. Again, we were greeted by name by the hostess and the waiter (Freddie). The dining room is very nice, set in a soaring palapa with rich dark wood everywhere. Of course, we began with margaritas (ranging in price from US$9 to US$12). They were great -- not the best ever -- but very good. We were presented with a complimentary amuse bouche (a nice touch, but unmemorable). Appetizers were in the US$10 to US$20 range. We had a tuna and yellowtail tartare which was plentiful and very fresh. Most entrees were between US$20 and US$30, with some, like Caribbean lobster, much more expensive. I dined on short ribs (US$27), which were very tasty and perfectly cooked. My companion had seafood couscous (US$32), which I tasted and liked a small bit more than my own choice. The shellfish with the dish was plentiful and absolutely perfectly cooked. As we finished our entrees, Freddie suggested that we ordered a passion fruit souffle, which takes extra preparation time. We took him up on the offer and I was very happy we did. It was served with homemade ice cream and really remarkable. I loved it from top to bottom. I recall it was around US$10 or US$15. The only slight surprise on the bill was a US$10 charge per large bottled water (we had two). It is important to note that the Fairmont has it's own supply of clean, safe drinking water and, by law, all ice served in any restaurant must be from purified water. From that point on, we drank tap water and never had a problem. The following morning, we dined at La Laguna for breakfast. Not great, not horrible -- somewhere in between. They offered a buffet, but we ordered a la carte. Most a la carte breakfasts were in around US$12 or US$15. I also ordered a basket of Mexican breads and pastries that was tasty and plentiful for US$5. Orange juice was US$4 per glass. I ordered the breakfast burrito, my girlfriend had the Mexican hash skillet. The food was very good. The service was a little sluggish, although there was a large, somewhat needy party at the next table. Overall, it seemed that the service staff would have preferred we just order the buffet and seemed inconvenienced by the need to serve us a la carte. Again, certainly friendly service, just a little sluggish. On the second day of our stay, we dined poolside at the beach (amazing guacamole with salsa and chips for US$10 and really, really good ceviche for US$17). Drinks poolside were nicely prepared, especially the pina colada. Again, US$9 to US$12 for margaritas and frozen drinks, US$6 for local beer. I'm a big tequila fan and was swilling a pretty pricey number on Saturday afternoon, at US$15 per shot. It was good, but not my favorite. Before leaving, we dined at the lobby bar. Had the guacamole again and a fairly large cheese and mushroom pizza (US$17), which tasted like something I could make at home with a pre-packaged crust. Margaritas in the lobby bar were tasty. Try the Cadillac or the Mango. Off property, we dined in Playa del Carmen at Yaxtche (great meal, and a good value at around US$60 with drinks and dessert). We also dined at Ambar at the Mandarin Oriental (also excellent, a little pricer than Las Brisas -- we went kind of crazy since it was our last night, and they also had really good martinis, so our tab topped US$300). Both of our off property choices were arranged and recommended by the concierge desk. There is 24-hour room service, which we did not try. Also, there is no mini bar in the room, but you can go to the resort's market and cafe and pick out items that they will stock for you in your refrigerator and replenish each day. We also did not do this. We did purchase some alcohol in duty free on the way and made drinks in the room to save a bit on the prices. Service: Really, really top notch. Some highlights: Marco, the concierge, who I communicated with via email before our arrival to arrange dinner reservations; Ricardo, the boat driver who took us on a really cool 45-minute lagoon tour (free, just make a reservation in advance), slowed down the boat to point out all sorts of fish, birds and neat features of the man-made lagoon cut into limestone and connected to underground rivers, and was very patient in answering all of our questions; and Alfredo at the front desk who had security open the gift shop after hours so my girlfriend could get some Advil (delivered directly to the room with no extra charge). Everyone was warm and friendly and it made for such a pleasant experience. I cannot imagine anyone complaining about service at this resort. Calls for bellmen or service are responded to promptly, somewhat surprising considering how large and spread out the resort is. Housekeeping comes twice a day, and leaves bottled water around the room. After calling, valet had our car waiting out front by the time we reached the lobby. The lone service hiccup was at breakfast mentioned above. And, the warm 'Hola' extended by virtually everyone (again, often followed by our names) made for such a happy experience for us both. Checkout: Quick and easy. Honestly, this is the first time I can ever recall being in Latin America and not finding errors on the bill. We finished lunch in the lobby bar and immediately walked to the front desk to check out and our tab from lunch was already on my account. Most hotels in the U.S. can't even accomplish this. Be aware that there is a US$15 daily resort fee that includes gratuities (although we did tip regularly, and more for particularly exceptional service -- i.e., 50 pesos (around US$4) for housekeeping each day, 100 pesos for the boat ride). Valet parking is US$14/day. U.S. currency is widely accepted on property. The front desk will exchange currency at competitive rates with no surcharge. The ATM on property dispenses U.S. currency. Billing is done in pesos, with a conversion at the bottom. So, after all this, why doesn't Fairmont Mayakoba earn five stars? For my girlfriend, it was the breakfast at La Laguna -- a service hiccup that kind of stuck with us. For me, there was one really big, glaring problem that was constantly an issue. The bath towels are way below par for a 5-star resort. One of the things I love most about high end hotels are large, plush bath towels. The bath towels at Fairmont Mayakoba are neither. In fact, they were stiff and kind of scratchy -- consistently same each day. What's really remarkable is that the towels at the pool are large and soft. There must be some sort of issue in the laundry process. Attention really needs to be paid to this. Overall, I wouldn't hesitate to return, especially on a good deal. Most of all, I hope this detailed report gives you the confidence to book your own vacation at this amazing property in Riviera Maya!

Reviews.Title: “beautiful bathroom”
Reviews.Author: anam01
Reviews.Content: Lobby, rooms and pools are very nice. Big and luxury rooms and beds, nice ambience, but food at the resort´s restaurants is not as good as they charge for.

Reviews.Title: “A Fantastic Family Trip!”
Reviews.Author: Menomineelk
Reviews.Content: To anyone considering a vacation to this property all I can say is, GO! We were just down there for the kids school break. The staff was excellent, property beautiful, and over all just a great vacation! There is really nothing else to say except perhaps to rent a car. We had diner in Playa Del Carmen several times, spent a day at Xel-Ha, and went to Cozumel for a day. These events were all much less complicated because we had a car. Not to mention getting to and from the airport was a breeze(30 min drive). Even though the hotel was sold out it felt empty. Golf is great! All I can say is Go!

Reviews.Title: “Pretty Good! I would go back.”
Reviews.Author: RoryHeidi
Reviews.Content: We loved the grounds and the settings of the resort. The staff was ok...not Ritz Carlton good, but better than a normal hotel or all-inclusive resort. If you can't walk well - do not stay here. Walking to and from is essential. We stayed in a Castia that had a lagoon view and I would very highly recommend paying extra for the view. The food in all of the restaurants was good and NOT expensive for a luxury resort. Drinks were between 5 and 7.50 and guac was 90/14 so around 6.50 USD. De Vino in town was our favorite restaurant. If you are looking to party - don't stay here. Trust me.

Reviews.Title: “god awful for the $$$$”
Reviews.Author: rogue026
Reviews.Content: The resort is truly gorgeous, this I will say. The rooms are luxurious and chic, the grounds stunning. That being said, for the money we paid to stay here, we truly got just a plush room and beautiful view, and nickel and dimed on everything else. To start with, the layout is horrible. It is a 15 minute walk to the beach, which was rocky with murky water and overridden with gnats. The many pools throughout the resort were nice, however. With all of the lagoons and jungle walkways, you would not expect it to be a very kid-friendly place, however I found myself kept awake at night by shrieking children (or banshees, more appropriately) who apparently were running rampant throughout the resort at all hours of the night. They also took over the pools and common areas so there was not an ounce of feeling of relaxation. We spent over $100 on dinner that you couldn't pay me to eat again, in fact it made me quite ill. The staff was great, though they all seemed nervous that someone would complain about something. In fact, none of the guests appeared happy at all at this resort, though I suspect it is just the kind of people this place attracts and not the the resort or it's staff. At checkout we were charged twice for the room and then charged for valet parking after we were given no option but to valet on arrival. On this trip my husband and I stayed in 3 resorts in the Riviera Maya and this was by far the worst, though it was the most expensive of all. I do not recommend this resort at all, unfortunately.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing looking resort”
Reviews.Author: eknighton
Reviews.Content: My spouse and I, as well as his parents stayed here from March 1-5th for a Business Convention. It is very beautiful and luxurious. It is set among mangrove jungle and underground rivers and covers over 200 acres. Most of the rooms are casitas which have a room upstairs and downstairs, some of them are set along the canals. You have to do a lot of walking at this resort since everything is so spread out. It was a 20 minute walk to the beach from our room which was near the lobby/convention centre building but we would always hop on a golf cart or take a bike. The carts go by every few minutes and if you see a bike, you just take it and leave it at the bike rack where you stop. The beach is beautiful and you can walk for miles in either direction. I never actually went in the water at the beach though since it was quite cool and very windy that day. They have a restaurant, and pool at the beach. They have a restaurant and a huge maze like pool near the middle of the resort and an adults only pool overlooking the canal. There is also another restaurant in the lobby but I never saw it open. There is also another pool by the lobby that I never went near. The rooms are beautiful. We stayed in a casita that was not on the canal. It was on the ground floor so we didn't have a view of anything but trees. Too huge closets to store your stuff in. 4 of us stayed in one room comfortably. There is a mini fridge but they don't stock it. There is a safe big enough to store your laptop. The bathroom was beatiful behind 2 large wooded sliding doors, it opens up into a marble bathroom with an atrium taking up one wall beside the soaker tub. The is the benefit of being on the groud floor since the rooms upstairs only have a small window in the bathroom. Toilet was seperated by a door so that more than one person could the facilites. 2 sinks, soaker tub and a huge walkin shower with glass wall and rainfall shower head. Food was great, not all inclusive but the prices weren't too bad actually. They have a great fitness centre and spa. We had a couples message that was terrific. When you have a spa treatment, you also get to use the pool and hot tub on the spa roof that is open until 8pm. All the other pools at the resort close at 5 amd there is no other hot tub to use. I beleive you can pay $25 a day if you want to use the spa facilites. The resort was great except that it really got quite boring at night. There is no entertainment, and the bars were always empty and closed early. We ended up just going back to our rooms most nights to watch tv and go to sleep early. The resort seemed really empty, but maybe because it is so spread out....I probably wouldn't bring my kids here either. Nothing for them to do and so much walking... They have a great golf course here. Some of the holes are right at the beach. They actually a pga tournament going on during our stay. Free internet in you room if you are a member of the Fairmont Presidents Club which is free to join.

Reviews.Title: “awesome”
Reviews.Author: hollygirlChico_Ca
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Mayakoba Resort March 7th through the 12th with a large group. I have never been to Mexico and have always instead gone to Maui for family "beach" vacations. I felt safe in Hawaii and always questioned Mexico. I was totally wrong. The people at this resort were always trying to make us comfortable and tending to every need. For anyone like myself that wants a comparison to Hawaii......here you go. The beach at the Mayakoba was the most beautiful I have ever seen. The white beach and the green/blue water was something I have never seen. The lounge chairs and huts on the beach were so comfortable. My husband is a shade guy so it was wonderful to have this for free. (the shade was $35 per day at my last resort in Maui) The men that served food and drinks at the beach were very friendly and I thought the prices were reasonable. The rooms were very nice. The bathroom was a focal point. I took pictures from every angle to show friends at home. The bed and pillows were great. We had a view of the lagoon which was nice. A lot of people have written in about the long walk to the beach. The golf carts take you anywhere you want to go and they drive by often. We never waited more than 5 or 6 minutes for a cart and we were told that the resort was completely full. There were only a couple things I would recommend for this resort. The pools were a bit cold. I am sure this is nice when it's hot in the summer but we had very pleasant weather, 85 or so. The pool was too cold. The other thing is there is a deli next to the pool but it is very limited on items. There needs to be more snack items and more variety. Sometimes you just don't feel like having a sit down meal and it would be nice to grab a small snack to go. Other than that I would go back tomorrow if I could.

Reviews.Title: “Very relaxing stay”
Reviews.Author: travplaces
Reviews.Content: We have just returned from a 5 night stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba. While we liked it very much, we did not love it. The Pros Very much a 5 star resort in its attention to customer service. Very beautiful setting rooms very spacious and clean-beds very comfortable bathrooms enormous and clean Staff is extremely friendly, helpful and just plain nice food was very good, better at Las Brisas then at La Laguna Great fitness center Pools are beautiful,,,but cold Drinks and appetizers at the beach are good and service was excellent. The Cons Beach is too far from everything, you need to take a shuttle or bikes and there just aren't enough bikes on the premises and those that are there are not in great condition. Very windy at beach (in March) Do not go expecting to lounge in Caribbean type waters... very choppy, but still beautiful The resort does not offer any water sports at all Best restaurants are in Playa del Carmen, a 15 minute cab ride No lobby bar....place is desolate at 9 pm. Pools are not heated...very cold. So if the beach is choppy and the pools are freezing....not too many places to comfortably cool off. Since I was traveling with 2 young adults, it was just a bit too quiet for us. Very important tip: join the presidents club at fairmont.com if you are going to go there. You will then be able to get into the fitness center without an additional charge of $10 per day per person. If the hotel is not full they will also give you an upgrade if you are a member of the presidents club

Reviews.Title: “Tops for the Mayan penninsula”
Reviews.Author: WillemSpike
Reviews.Content: We very much enjoyed the hotel, the casitas were simply the best and the service was as always wtih the Fairmont chain simply fantastic. The food was top notch and staff friendly and not hesittant to assist at any time of day. If you are looking for a resort with quality patrons and service you can not ask for better. The beach and environmental concept is the standard that should be immitated by others. We higly recomend the property as a romantic getaway which is also sutable for pre teen age kids. We will most certainly return.

Reviews.Title: “We will return to the Fairmont Pierre Marques in Acapulco next year”
Reviews.Author: Marquez
Reviews.Content: Our stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba was okay. For the past several years, we have stayed at the Fairmont Pierre Marques in Acapulco. We will return to the Pierre Marques next year. Pros: -We had a beautiful one bedroom suite with lagoon and jungle views. We were able to sit on our extra large balcony and watch the birds and fish. -The staff at the main restaurant where they serve breakfast were wonderful. Specifically, the managers Roberto and Leslie and all of the servers. - Great adult only pools. Some beautiful infinity pools. -Truly a beautiful resort set in the jungle. Very modern with up-to-date amenities and huge washrooms. -Food at the resort was tasty. We really enjoyed the breakfast at La Laguana and we had a great dinner at the fanciest place, Las Brisas. We dined twice at El Puerto, the steak & seafood restaurant. Food was great at El Puerto but the service was spotty. -We don’t have kids but it looked like they had an amazing kids program. - Most staff will address you by name which is a nice touch. -The Willow Stream Spa was fantastic. I had the Honey in the Heart treatment which was incredible and my husband had a sports massage. I was blown away by my treatment. Our manicures and pedicures were nice but overpriced. No surprise there. Overall, the spa is fabulous. Also, there is a great gym. I attended a pilates class and was the only person in the class. That was kind of fun. Cons -The hotel gave us a room with two double beds. We had requested a king size bed. They did try to find us another room in the same category but the view was not as good so we opted to keep the room with the double beds. Also, the phone and internet needed to be fixed the first night as did a light bulb. I should note that both issues were fixed quickly. -The service was inconsistent. Sometimes there was great service at the pool, other times you wouldn’t see anyone until after noon. Some restaurant servers were amazing, others were okay. -The resort is so big that you essentially have to take shuttle from one end to the other. We stationed ourselves at the adults only infinity pool in the middle of the resort because it was less windy than the pool near the beach. If we wanted to go to the beach, we had to take a 5-10 minute shuttle ride. -Although Playa Del Carmen was only about 15-20 minutes away, the beach wasn't the greatest. Overall, the Fairmont Mayakoba is a truly gorgeous property. However, the inconsistent service, not-so-great weather (some rain, loads of clouds, extremely cool breeze and not high temperatures) and the distance to the beach for people who cannot afford a $2,500 oceanfront casita (apparently, that’s how much is costs according to one of the employees) means that we will not return. One other note for President’s Club members: There is not a private check-in for members. We had to ask for someone from the President’s Club. We are Platinum members and have been for several years. That’s why were astonished that they would have provided us a room with double beds when that was not what we requested and the fact that we’re Platinum members really didn’t make a difference. The lack of importance for Platinum President’s Club members was an issue for us. At the Fairmont Pierre Marques, we are treated like royalty. Restaurant Recommendation: If you’re looking for amazing local seafood, try El Oasis Mariscos just off 5th Avenue. We had the best meal of our trip there…shrimp tacos and “awesome” seafood paella.

Reviews.Title: “This is what dreams are made of”
Reviews.Author: Be_devine
Reviews.Content: When I am stressed, I think of my stay at the Mayakoba and it seems to get all better. We stayed there for four nights after attending a work conference near Tulum. I've stayed at several placed in the Riviera Maya, and this is by far the best place I've stayed. In fact, I think I would rank this as the best hotel experience I've ever had. Our first night was in a Private Casita, which was set back from the ocean but had great ocean views from the private rooftop pool. The roof sprang a leak during the torrential rains overnight and, after some exceptionally quick and professional problem solving on the hotel's part, we were moved to an Private Oceanfront Casita. This is the one in the pictures that has the private pool looking out over the ocean. Every morning, I would make coffee and walk out to our private palapa just a few steps from the casita. The suite is very large with a full living room, a huge bedroom, and two bathrooms. The master bathroom has glass walls looking out to a private garden. Simply breathtaking. We ate at La Laguna and Las Brisas. Both were very good with excellent service. Las Brisas is expensive, but it's worth it as a splurge. We also did a "cooking class" with their Executive Chef. It wasn't so much a cooking class as a kitchen tour. But the Exec. Chef was great and I was impressed with the lengths that the hotel goes to to ensure sanitation and food safety. The staff is very attentive. Pretty much any wish you ask will be granted. Our private butler even offered to unpack for us, which we declined. The only thing I would caution is that this property is very large and very spread out. Getting to the beach from the main hotel complex is a 5 min. golf cart ride. But they do have bicycles all around the property, and that's a fun way to get around. If you're staying in the private area by the beach, it's the same ride to get up to the main complex where most of the restaurants are, but the oceanfront restaurant (Las Brisas) is just a short walk from the private area). This was an unforgettable four days and I can't wait to go back.

Reviews.Title: “Best kept secret near Playa del Carmen”
Reviews.Author: mas73
Reviews.Content: The Fairmont Mayakoba is a beautifully maintained resort that lives up to its 5-star rating. My husband and I spent 5 nights here in January and absolutely loved it. We have been to the Riviera Maya two other times and stayed at very nice resorts but neither of these resorts compared to the Fairmont in terms of the beauty of the property, comfort and luxury of the accommodations, and the impeccable service. The beach is fairly wide and nicely kept; however, it is approximately 1/2 a mile from most of the resort rooms (there are some rooms located beach-side). It's a leisurely walk, bike ride (bikes provided by the hotel), or convenient golf cart-ride from the staff that frequently travels back-and-forth to the beach. My husband and I can't wait to go back!

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel, Some Minor Missteps”
Reviews.Author: annualparkvisitor
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just got back from our stay at Fairmont Mayakoba. Overall, the resort is wonderful. The property is gorgeous. It is large, but my husband and I enjoyed that aspect. Yes, the beach is far from most rooms but it can easily be reached by a long leisurely walk, a quick bike ride or any of the carts which pass by regularly. The beach itself is well-maintained and service is excellent. In fact, the service everywhere was excellent. The main pool area is beautiful and service is excellent. But, the pools were very cold..too cold to swim in. The rooms are wonderful. I highly recommend joining the President's club because they will upgrade your room if they are not at full capacity and you get free in room internet access. The rooms are spacious and clean. The bed is a bit hard (I find this with most hotels in Mexico) and my husband and I woke up several times in the night because of this. The bathroom is very spacious and modern. The food and drink are probably the biggest drawback of this resort. It is definitely not four star resort food and drink. In fact, it is closer to the quality of an average all-inclusive. Overall the food was bland and average and the drinks did not taste like they had any alcohol in them. We ended up going to Playa del Carmen the last few nights just to get some decent meals (Playa is about 15-20 minute (and 15-20 dollar cab ride, but I would highly recommend traveling there for evening shopping, drinks and dinner). We do however recommend visiting the Cafe Maya (the little convenience store at the Fairmont) and getting snacks and drinks for the room. The Cafe is also a good place for a cheap breakfast (a bagel or muffin). We agree with other reviewers that they do seem to nickel and dime you a bit. The bland food is not cheap (although admittedly not outrageously expensive for a four star resort). Also, the resort fee and the daily service charges are an unwelcome add-on. When you are calculating the nightly room rate, you really need to add on $25 or so. Overall, if the cleanliness, quality and modernity of the rooms and the natural features of the property are important to you then I highly recommend staying here. We stayed in a lagoon villa and we saw wildlife all the time including fish and turtles in the lagoon and birds in the trees and our porch. We absolutely loved the property itself. If you are looking for a resort with amazing food to eat all your meals at then this is not the resort for you.

Reviews.Title: “The service was the cherry on top!”
Reviews.Author: kguerra
Reviews.Content: The Fairmont Mayakoba is a beautiful sprawling modern resort. It truly makes a great impression upon seeing it. It is really not as big as it seems at first. We found it very easy to get around. Lots of modern pools to go around and they all provided a nice ambiance. But what really stood above all was the wonderful service we encountered from everyone there. We stayed in a Signature Casita in the 300 block and it was simply gorgeous. Our huge terrace overlooked the canals and it was so nice to go out there in the morning. The bedroom was great, so big and clean. The bed was super comfy as well as the pillows. We ate at all the restaurants except El Puerto and we even had service at the pool and lounge (delicious sushi). The food was pretty good and the prices very reasonable. The service provided by everyone who served us was magnificent. There is nothing to complain about there. We also rented a car at the Hertz on the property and drove down to Tulum. I would highly recommend it. You also do not pay overnight valet at the Fairmont if you rent from the Hertz on site. There was nothing that was too big or too small for the staff to accommodate. They were great! Always with a smile, super polite and they remembered your name. I would definitely stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba next time I visit the Riviera Maya.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel, Excellent Service”
Reviews.Author: sox05
Reviews.Content: We just returned from the Fairmont Mayakoba after a wonderful stay with our four year old boy. Everything was great (except for weather) Service was exceptional. We stayed in a casita by the beach and it was a long hall back to the kids pool / lobby, etc. The next time I go I will either stay in a fairmont room in the main building or a suite because the upgrade to a casita was not worth it. the food at la puerta in the lobby was excellent but the other restaraunts were average ( we did not eat at the fine dining restrnt Las Brisas). Ate at the neighboring Rosewood twice and it was excellent. I will stay at the Rosewood if I go back without my son, but for kids I think Fairmont much better option. Recomend renting a car and eating in Playa del Carmen a few nights. We ate at John Grays, ristorante di bruno, and divino and all three were great. Golf at El Cameleon was great so if you golf bring your clubs because rental charge is high and balls are very expensive. Only complaint I have is that I felt the staff should spend more time cleaning up beach and pool area.

Reviews.Title: “Should be better to be a "5 Star" Venue”
Reviews.Author: scotth42
Reviews.Content: First time travelling to Mexico although have been all over the world at many 5 star hotels. Picked this location to relax and chill with family. Picked this hotel because of "5 star rating". Positives: Quick unremarkable check in process "Upgraded" to Deluxe casita (same as regular except on lagoon) Hotel room was nice and clean with better than average bathrooms. Beautiful grounds Nice gym and spa Very good buffet breakfast Uncrowded Negatives: Average food and drinks Expensive food and drinks All 3 restaurants NOT open at times which limits your choices as to where to eat Pools are not heated and are very cold Distance to ocean Multiple incorrect items on bill at check out Too much construction going on around pool area that limited our ability to relax Staff is friendly but not trained to 5 star standards

Reviews.Title: “Excellent but only if you get a good deal on the price”
Reviews.Author: NYCNYers
Reviews.Content: I have mixed feelings about this resort. It's lovely and I felt relaxed after staying there, but I wouldn't stay there again unless I got a 4-night package including airfare for $1000---which is what I paid this time. The hotel is luxurious and beautiful, but there are just too many little kinks to justify paying more. First, as many other reviewers have mentioned, the beach is far away from most rooms. The only rooms right on the beach are expensive villas/suites. The logistic of getting to the beach isn't too bad. There was always a golf cart driven by a friendly staff member to get you around. But it was just weird---my room was 1 kilometer from the beach. I couldn't even hear the ocean at night or in the morning, which is one of my favorite things about staying at a beach resort. And the restaurant on the beach didn't open until noon. The beachfront pool area was just so-so; nowhere near as nice as the main pool area that was not on the beach. I understand the non-beach pool has to be supernice to make up for not being on the beach, but I don't understand why the beach pool has to be mediocre--it was just a straightforward infinity pool with white mesh chairs. Second, the food was just ok. Some of the room service was downright awful. Third, I saw a few bugs in the room --- nothing that bothered me much, mainly tiny spiders and silverfish, but worth noting for more squeamish people. Fourth, I was outraged that they charged $10 to use the gym. It just makes you feel like you're getting bamboozled. The good news is that the resort is beautiful. The golf cart ride to the beach is very scenic and relaxing. You're a 15-minute cab ride from Playa del Carmen proper (cheesy nightclubs, bars, etc.). The beach never got crowded so I didn't have to worry about taking that 1-kilometer golf cart ride only to not be able to find a good spot, although that may have been because of the recession. The staff is incredibly friendly and helpful. And, while the place was crawling with kids, there are enough nooks and crannies for them to entertain themselves so they don't overwhelm the place.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome trip”
Reviews.Author: meags163
Reviews.Content: The staff was extremely nice. The room was clean and spacious. The beach and pools were beautiful. The food at the restaurant was great. Not too crowded and we were able to practice our spanish with the staff who were eager to practice with us. The hotel room was not right near the beach but it is an easy bike ride or you can hop on one of the golf carts. The hotel is about 40 minutes from Cancun and 10-15 from Playa del Carmen. Very convenient weekend getaway!

Reviews.Title: “Great Second Stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba”
Reviews.Author: vacationhat
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just returned from a 5 night stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba. This is the second time in 3 years that we have vacationed at this property. Everything was as we remembered it - Lovely! The property and the rooms are clean and well maintained. The spa is a must. The beach is fabulous. The staff is so gracious and accommodating. I can't wait to vacation at the Fairmont again.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the spa and the bathrooms so nice!”
Reviews.Author: mayita24
Reviews.Content: I liked the hotel a lot! I had not stayed at a fairmont before and was not expecting it to be such a nice property. The hotel is pretty new so you can expect the rooms to be super clean and well maintained, the bathrooms are wonderful! and the rooms are huge! the beds reaaaaally comfy, not too soft not too firm, AC worked perfectly, no noise from neighbors. They have dvd player, flat screen TV, big closet, minibar that you can get stocked with your choosings. We stayed in one of the casitas in the forrest, and it was perfect. The resort is big so you need to use golf carts to move around the property but they are always available. The BEACH WAS PHENOMENAL, and the bar there serves the best cocktails I ever tasted. The food is not great at all besides sushi at the lobby lounge, and service can be rude sometimes, not trained well enough to make your stay more memorable. I am talking about servers in the restaurants, the guys that drive the golf carts...but the housekeeping staff is awesome. Concierge 3/10, front desk whatever but they did help my husband retrieve his Blackberry that he left in a random taxi that dropped us in the airport at 4am! so maybe they were effective but lets say just not gracious enough. All in all I would return if I got the wedding rate we got becuase a friend got married there. But the property is pretty amazing.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Place”
Reviews.Author: DBK66
Reviews.Content: My wife and I and our 2 children (boys - 5 & 3) stayed at the Mayakoba for 8 nights March 17-25 of 2008. We debated greatly over whether to go to Beaches Turks or the Riveria Maya and the Fairmont and we couldn't have been happier with our decision! The flight form Phila. to Cancun was on time easy and comfortable. Our transport from the airport to the Fairmont only took about 40 minutes and was also fairly simple. Cancun's newly remodled airport is small and very easy to navagate. They did a nice job. Check in at the Fairmont was great...cool towels, nice welcome cocktail and then off to our room. We stayed in a signature casita which was very spacious. Two queen size beds (very comfortable) and huge bathroom. Our room also had a private deck which overlooked the lagoon. The 4 of us were plenty comfortable..lots of room to spread out in. The resort has 3 pools. The main pool, while all connected, is sort of broken up into different sections. The slide area seemed the most crowed (but not really crowed) because it had the most kids and thus was the loudest section. Other areas seemed faily private and quite and that's were we would go for our pool side lunches. The adult only pool was a beautiful infiniety pool and was very peaceful. The beach pool (also an infinity pool) was also very nice and quite as well. The beach was awesome! Few rocks, but for the most part soft buttery sand and beautiful turquoise water. We played in that water for hours at a time. It was so warm and soothing. There seemed to be plenty of Palapas (beach umbrellas). We never had to get up early rush down to the beach to reserve one which was nice. The beach service is great and we had a few lunches down there. The resort is very expansive, so be prepared to walk a little bit. If you get tired there is always a golf cart passing by to take you to whereever it is that you want to go. I've read other reviewers who've said that they had to wait quite a while for a cart to come by, but we did not find this to be the case. There were plenty of them roaming the resort to take guest anywhere they wanted to go. The staff were extremely friendly and very helpful thoughout our stay and we appreciated their kindness and warm welcoming "holas!" They all seemed very gracious. We ate at all three restaurants and thought the food was very good. It wasn't great dining, but very good. And yes, it is a little expensive, but we read about that before we went. We always found something we like on the menus, kids too. We also like to explore and had some really good dinners in Playa...Alux and Yatche were really good and a nice change from the resort menus. We also took a couple of day trips. Xel-Ha was amazing! We snorkeled, swam and ate from 10 am. until 5 pm..For the price of admission ($75 adult / $50 per child = tranasportation ) snorkel gear, food, drinks, towels and lockers are provided. you'll be in your bathing suit the entire day! The water is incrediblly crystal clear and warm, just about every color of fish that you can imagine and just a beautifully and tastefully designed eco park. Thank goodness Disney doesn't own it! We all loved it and I would highly recommend it. Xcaret was also beautiful. It has a really nice zoo (nice for kids) and maybe a little more in the way of cultural activities. If your still standing at the end of the day they have a really cool historical reenactment of the Mayan civilazation that takes place in this outdoor, but covered ampatheatere. Very interesting and creatitive and filled with culture and historal montages! Our kids really enjoyed it too. The resort was mostly adults and couples and I'd say about 1/5 of the guests were families with small chikdren (under 12). Our kids really enjoyed the kids program and the girls that run it do a nice job of keeping the kids interested and involved with different activities. We loved the kids program too beacuse it gave my wife and I a chance to unwind and try the spa which we did a handfull of times. We had masages, reflexology, baths, steams......it was great! A little on the expensive side, but what the heck, it's vacation! Over all we had a terrific vacation. Great family time, in a beautiful place with fun and interesting things to do, good restuarants and lots of cultural richness! This was our 5th time visiting Mexico, second in the Riveria Maya, and we've really enjoyed it! If you have any question please feel free to send an eamil. Enjoy your visit to the Fairmont Mayakoba. You will love it!

Reviews.Title: “Not the place for us”
Reviews.Author: rangeley
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 3 nights at the end of our two week wedding celebration/honeymoon in Playa del Carmen. Having been in downtown Playa for 11 nights with a lot of friends and family we were looking forward to total relaxation for a few nights before heading home. We were in a signature casita which is a very nice room that overlooks the lagoon. The bed was so wonderful and the room was modern and spacious. But we were so far from the beach! The property is so large and spread out that you have to walk, ride bikes (during the day only & the bikes we tried were pretty beat up), or wait for a golf cart to drive by and pick you up. All of the dining outlets are good (not great) and definitely overpriced - which we, of course, expected. I liked that they pass out cucumbers for your eyes at the beach and check in on you often if you need anything. But, they continually mis-pronounced my last name, over and over, probably 80 times in 3 days. I know this is a 5 star standard, to say the guest’s name, but it gets very annoying to continually correct them again and again on your vacation. We obviously know that this type of property is not for us but we made the most of it and relaxed at the beach each day, rode bikes, walked and tried the different restaurants. When we were leaving I asked the concierge how much a cab was to the airport which they said was $49 (I thought this was pricy because a cab all the way to Playa, which is south of Mayakoba by 20 minutes, is only $45). Regardless, I said this was fine and they arranged a nice taxi for us to take to the airport. When we arrived the driver said the fare was $60 and the Fairmont was not correct in saying it was $49. We wondered how we managed to have great experiences with many taxis all over Playa for almost two weeks and then we get the 5 star Fairmont and get ripped off. There are so many great small hotels and wonderful restaurants in Playa and the surrounding area I don’t know why anyone would want to be so secluded and limited at a large resort.

Reviews.Title: “Wish I could have stayed”
Reviews.Author: Santamonicagirl
Reviews.Content: What an amazing place the Fairmont Mayakoba is. This property has so much to offer. You can spend your day relaxing by a number of pools or go and sit on the beach. The restaurants are all really good, but our favorite was La Puerta which is only open for dinner (be sure to make a reservation). The staff is exceptional at this resort. The are all extremely polite and curteous. They go out of their way to make sure you are well taken care of. One thing come prepared with bug spray.

Reviews.Title: “Flawless Visit!”
Reviews.Author: alison50000
Reviews.Content: The Fairmont Mayakoba is a beautiful property! The rooms are great - stayed in a Casita which is a step above from a Standard room but not a Suite. Service - Fantastic! The service was way beyond expectations. Every staff member really wants to make sure you are happy and greet you at all times. Not so much to make it annoying - it's just very genuine. Property - Great! I was there on a business/pleasure trip and it surpassed all expectations. The hotel was sold out yet it did not feel crowded. Anytime I had an issue or was concerned about anything, the staff made sure to resolve immediately...such a rare thing these days. I am not impressed that often but if you like to be in a beautful place and like to have great service - I would highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Hotel”
Reviews.Author: SSemone
Reviews.Content: I had a wonderful time at this resort. We ended up getting a deal on a suite which included $100 dollars a day credit for any facility at the hotel, which I used at the Spa, and a breakfast buffet every day. The room was beautiful with two bathrooms, one with an outdoor shower, and a seating area with TV. There was a deck that overlooked a cenote and golf course. The room was lovely. The food was great, the spa was absolutely fabulous. They know how to treat you at the spa, there were cookies, muffins, fruits, and juices there for people while they wait for there service. The services were also wonderful and there was a pool and mineral soak to be used with spa pass. There was a nice small gym with a schedule of classes every day. I did Yoga one day and I was the only one in there, so I essentially got a private yoga instruction. Ok, now back to the hotel. The room service was yummy, I had a seafood wrap that I loved, the food at the beach was great-- scallops for me. The food at the upscale restaurant was not good. Not worth it at all. There were lots of kids at this resort, but they had a special pool area for them. The beach did tend to get a bit crowded, but you could still get a beach chair. All in all a great place. Also join the Fairmont's Presidents Club-it is free and you get free spa/gym access with it as well as upgrades on later travels.

Reviews.Title: “Incredible Experience”
Reviews.Author: cubsfan73
Reviews.Content: My family (my wife, our 8 month old, and her parents) spent a week at the Fairmont Mayakoba and found it to be a wonderful hotel. The hotel grounds are beautiful and visitors will feel as if they are in the depth of the Mayan jungle before the hotel comes into view. The staff is very friendly and greets all visitors with juice and towels. The Front Desk is accomodating; our requested crib (with stuffed animals) and high-chair were waiting in our room. The hotel is great for kids. There are a lot of families around and the staff is very attentive to the kids' needs. As described in some of the other posts, the hotel may be better for those with kids rather than those on a romantic getaway. On the other hand, the property is so big that honeymooners (and we saw a few) would likely have fun. We had a casita near the canals and the rooms/bathrooms were large and comfortable. The water was hot, the A/C worked. Housekeeping was attentive and thorough. The restaurants are a little pricey (it is a secluded resort), but there is nice variety in the menus. The service is incredible. Everyone from the guys at the pool to the waitresses were extremely hospitable and friendly. The service alone would make us want to return. The beach (unless you are staying at one of the beachfront casitas) is a 10-15 minute walk or a 5-10 minute golf cart ride. The hotel provides bicycles to its guests and it is a very pleasant 5 minute bike ride to the beautiful beach. There is also a boat service that traverses the underground river fed canals to the beach dock. Yes, it would be nice to have a beach view, but it is an entirely different experience to stay by the canals. If you want a pure beach location, this hotel may disappoint you. The hotel is about 20 minutes by taxi (fixed price 170 pesos) to Playa del Carmen. It is nice to get away for a dinner or a day trip to the town. There was no snorkelling off the hotel beach, but the in-house travel agency could coordinate (at competitive prices) snorkel/scuba trips. The golf course is beautiful and spa was the definition of serenity, but you will pay for those luxuries. In conclusion, this is an exceptional hotel in a beautiful setting that is great for families with kids. The most remarkable part of the hotel is the service and we will likely return to this hotel for that reason.

Reviews.Title: “Heaven on Earth”
Reviews.Author: raqrelax
Reviews.Content: The Fairmont Mayakoba is heaven on earth. If you're looking for complete tranquility, this is the place to stay. The setting and natural landscape place you in a different world - the lagoon and paseos through the mangrove forest lead to the ocean - a perfect place for rejuvenation and baptism. The accomodations, from the condo units to the casitas, are very charming yet luxurious. The spa is awesome. Staff was friendly and attentive. There are enough restaurants and cafes on site if you choose to lay low, but you're only 10 minutes away from downtown (by taxi) if you'd like to experience more dining choices and a great nightlife. My boyfriend and I visited in June of 2007. We were looking for a spiritual experience - complete with serenity, tranquility, privacy, a natural setting (less commercialized), blue skies, clear water...but since we're from a major urban city we also wanted all the amenities. Mayakoba offered all of the above. We'll definitely return (and often do in memory). The owners were smart to designate a pool area specifically for children/families. The resort is attractive for families, but also for couples with no children who want peace and quiet.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Stay”
Reviews.Author: jtml0802
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Fairmont Mayakoba with my boyfriend and two other couples for 4 days and had an absolutely wonderful stay. We were all upgraded to casita rooms since it was down season. Grounds are beautiful. Very modern and clean cut, not as tacky as other resorts we have seen in the neighborhood. We never had to wait more than 5 minutes for one of the carts to come pick us up to get to the beach or the lobby. The pools are amazing, especially the adults only infinity pool by the lagoon. Room was nice with a comfortable bed and a spacious bathroom. The staff was also very helpful.. concierge made good recommendations for places to eat in Playa del Carmen. We also had one meal at Las Brisas and enjoyed it very much (although pricey, it is fine dining food). We loved the hotel as a nice place for rest and relaxation, but if you are looking for more entertainment and nightlife, somewhere in Playa del Carmen itself may be better for you. We will most definitely be visiting the Fairmont Mayakoba again!

Reviews.Title: “Birthday Trip”
Reviews.Author: stbarts08
Reviews.Content: Stayed July,21-27th. I've been traveling to the Yucatan for apprx. 20 years. My husband worked for a major airline and we've traveled the world. When we first traveled to Playa Del Carmen there were only 2 hotels, miles of beach to ourselves,town was a small fishing village. I've stayed at almost all of the higher end hotels in the area. My last trip was 2 years ago. This is the first time I stayed at a non-allinclusive hotel. I read all of the reviews before I going so I was prepared. First rent a car. Easy to drive. The hotel is seculded. The hotel is nice, but like everyone stated a distance from the beach. I perfer to have an ocean view. We arrived during tropical storm Doris. Some people talked about the rocky beach. Caused by storms in the area. There were some rocks the first few days then cleared up. Brought water shoes. The hotel was built in the jungle and they perserved the surrounding area ,which I appreciate. We had a Castias on the first floor that faced a lot of trees. Had an issues with spiders in the room and requested a change to the second floor, they accomodated our request. The rooms were very clean and serviced twice a day. Did not eat breakfast at the hotel. Lunch was good, a little pricey. Only ate dinner there our first night. Playa Del Carmen has turned into a crowed town with high end restaurants and bars. I prefer the quaint fishing village it used to be.Went to Puerto Morelos several times for dinner. Rustic small fishing town. I'm sure it will be the next town to change. There is a large supermarket in town ,two blocks away Walmart (larger selection of alcohol then supermarket but busy). There is a refrigerator in the room. Bought snacks,beer,wine and alcohol in town. There is a market on the property but pricey. Gas station across the street were you can buy drinks and snacks. I always bring a nylon cooler with me when I travel so I can take snacks and beverages with me to the beach or on excursions. You can view your bill daily on the TV and check out on line. The hotel charges $15 a day for the use of the golf carts,bikes and boats. $14 for valet parking if you have a car. Hotel tax think 12%. Don't golf looked like a nice course $186pp for guest. Very peaceful hotel, nice staff, pools were nice. Enjoyed the adults only pool. No entertainment have to go to town. Overall nice stay.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Hotel”
Reviews.Author: LH80
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I spent 2 nights at the hotel and loved it. We were lucky enough to get upgraded to a lagoon view cassita which was just gorgeous. Huge comfy bed, beautiful view, fantastic bathroom. Loved the swimming pools, split our time between the adults only infinity pool and by the beach. Only ate at one of the restaurants, the laguna, for lunch, and it was great. Prices were reasonable too. Only downside is its a bit far from Playa del Carmen or Cancun if you want to explore outside the hotel, and the taxi bills could add up quite quickly.

Reviews.Title: “Fairmont for Fabulous!”
Reviews.Author: LUXHEAD
Reviews.Content: This hotel is amazing! From the service to the rooms to the swimming pools... just a wonderful resort. I highly recommend it. The casitas feel like a luxury tree-house with lots of vegetation around it. The food is great with the only exception that the orange juice for breakfast is not fresh. It should be for a 5 diamond resort. Other than that it was perfect.

Reviews.Title: “Very relaxing hotel”
Reviews.Author: valifornia
Reviews.Content: We just got back from a quick jaunt to Playa Del Carmen -- we were in town for a friend's wedding and opted to stay at the Fairmont instead of one of the all-inclusive options. We loved the hotel -- the staff was incredibly friendly and for the most part, completely bilingual (although I speak Spanish, which was helpful at times). We liked the main pool, and the infinity pool by the beach was great. I think we benefited from being there during low season, though, because we never had to fight for a chair, etc. There was plenty of space for everyone. The hotel is large, but they do a great job of constantly running shuttles to help people get around. That said, we found the hotel completely walkable -- we only took the shuttles to and from our room upon check in an check out when we had luggage (as a disclaimer, we do a lot of walking/running at home). We ate at two of the restaurants, and, as hotel restaurants go, the food was good and the prices were reasonable. As for the rooms, we stayed in one of the casitas on the lagoon. Our bathroom had a full-size glass window that overlooked a totally private garden which was an interesting touch. We also had a patio overlooking the lagoon. We would completely recommend a similar room, and, if you're willing to spring the $1000 (or whatever it costs) for one of the beach front rooms, they looked amazing. If we ever decide we need a beach vacation, we'd consider staying at the Fairmont again. One word of warning -- simply uttering the words Fairmont at the airport or in town results in a pretty significant price increase in cab fares, etc. Be prepared to either pay a bit more and deal with it or negotiate.

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed the Mayakoba , kids loved it”
Reviews.Author: kem56
Reviews.Content: We were there June 27-July 4 and i really enjoyed the place. We travelled with 3 children , ages 6 and two 8yr olds so keep in mind my review is geared toward families. We were with a group of 17 and the hotel did a fantastic job of keeping us all together in the same area. When we arrived it was at 100 % occupancy and we heard when we left was at 20 % occupancy and I really didnt notice a difference. The place is very spread out and the pools are great. The kids pool has a slide and we loved it . The golf carts to the beach were not a big deal and the kids loved them. Advice : MUST BRING Water shoes and bug spray !! a must . The mosquitoes in the evening are merciless and the rocks in the ocean hurt. RENT A CAR- the hotel is fun but if you want to leave the hotel the taxi rates are extremely high ( $26.00 for a 5 mile trip to Xcaret) Its nice to try some other restaurants. We rented for a week for $125.00 We took an adventure to Xcaret - not sure if we would do this again because it was expensive for a family of 5. (75$ for adults/$40 for kids) It would have been great for half the price. They also charge by height and we are tall people so one of my kids was charged as an adult rate-painfull. We also went to Chichenitza and IK KIL Cenote - both were incredible and a must do . We had a rental car , left at 7 am and we on the ruins at 9. Spent 2-3 hours before the buses on tourist started to arrive . Go early !! Went to the cenote and that was a highlight too .

Reviews.Title: “LOVED the Mayakoba!”
Reviews.Author: cmb623
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed four nights at the Fairmont Mayakoba for our first anniversay. We LOVED it! The hotel is much bigger than we had imagined and it took us a full 24 hours to adjust and settle in to such a large piece of property. The grounds are very clean, yet also kept very natural and rustic. We stayed in the main Fairmont building. The room was all we needed minus a view. If we could change one thing about our stay at the Mayakoba it would be a high level room with a better view. Evenstill, the room was always clean with fresh towels and linens. The bed wasn't as soft and comfortable as I had expected though, but still better than most hotels. We ate at ALL of the restaurants on site and two downtown Playa del Carmen. The concierges should be your best friend while staying at the Fairmont--they never steared us wrong and were so kind and thoughtful! Everything on site is quite expensive, but it goes with the territory of such a luxurious resort I suppose. We LOVED the chips and fresh guacamole by the pool. We grabbed a quick breakfast at Cafe Maya everything morning (bagel w/cream cheese, yogurt, cereal, and the sorts), ate by the pool in the afternoon, and had a nice dinner every evening. The food is exquisite! La Laguna or Las Brisas are sure to impress. All in all, our trip was relaxing, exciting, and very enjoyable. The Fairmont Mayakoba is a great getaway!

Reviews.Title: “Very nice, but very spread out”
Reviews.Author: Beckett
Reviews.Content: If nothing else, this hotel is sprawling! No more than four stories high, but spread out so much that from the balcony of the main lobby, the ocean is but a sliver of blue stretched across the horizon. The main building contains a number of rooms (where we stayed), and the rest are scattered across as small blocks of casitas. Golf carts and bicycles are provided for transportation in addition to a boat which runs on a waterway towards the beach. What impressed us most was the spa. We got one of the best massages ever at the Fairmont. And the spa facilities were absolutely top notch. A plethora of soaking pools across two floors, a sun deck area, a big sitting area, and everything was very well kept. We didn't see many people at the spa while we were there, so we had the whole place to ourselves. Plus the fruit juices they have are quite tasty. Pictures posted by other reviewers of the beach are accurate and it is quite a lovely beach. But the entrance to the water has some rocks that one should be aware of. The beach at Tulum is many times better, but more on that later. Otherwise, it was great to take a swim in the warm ocean waters and hang out in the pool right by the beach. I do wish Fairmont does a better job at helping its guest get situated at the ocean or pool side chairs. The staff makes almost no attempt to discern whether chairs are really empty or whether they just haven't gotten around to taking away the dirty towels. It is pretty much a help yourself situation. In this regard, you really wished you were at a Four Seasons. Once you are situated, they are good about taking food and drink orders and the I would highly recommend the kobe beef hamburger at Las Brisas - the beach side restaurant. We ate at a couple of other restaurants at the Fairmont and they were fine. The prices were actually reasonable for a four star hotel. The room itself was good and had a large bathroom with a deep soaking tub. We did have small ants in the room, but given that you're in the tropics, that's pretty much a given. The linens were excellent - with very high thread count and down pillows were provided as well. Fairmont Mayakoba is one of those resorts where you don't have to leave the hotel through out the whole vacation. But I would recommend checking out the cenotes, the Mayan ruins, and especially the beach right next to the town of Tulum (about an hour south from the hotel). It is a big expanse of powder soft white sand beach lined with small bungalows. We'll be staying in Tulum next time round, but would definitely also come back to the Fairmont as well. Can't go back home without doing the spa!

Reviews.Title: “False advertising”
Reviews.Author: cocolandman
Reviews.Content: My main reason for selecting this resort was the photo of the "Moonlight Massage". Well, there is no "moonlight massage". The massages are all done inside the spa. When I asked why they mislead me in the advertisement, I was told, "well it is only a picture". Very, very unhappy. My one trip a year and it was really nothing special.

Reviews.Title: “Still recovering from Hurricane Dean”
Reviews.Author: Car4me
Reviews.Content: This was our second stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba; our first was cut short by Hurricane Dean last August so we decided to continue our stay in the Yucatan. They rebuilt and replaced the damages caused by the hurricane, did a good job, the only down fall was the beach, there are a lot of coral and rocks as you enter the beach, two rolls to be exact, and the water seams to not be as clear as before Dean. If only they can run some type of grader that would clear the sand of this. Or as I did, wear your water crocs. I would wait a few years before I re-visit the Fairmont Mayakoba for regrowth of the mangroves and surrounding vegetation. Once again the service was impeccable, and the staff is at your beck and call, as for the prices! They have not changed, still a bit pricey, yet the food is five stars. I don’t mind paying these prices for a good meal and something new to try, this is not your ordinary Mexican food that you would find in Baja. I do have a problem spending $25 U.S. Dollars on a bottle of sunscreen at the cafe. What I would recommend is what I did, have the daily buffet for $25 U.S. later in the morning, great selection of foods, and then a nice dinner for about $40 U.S. One last thing, I recommend for you to visit Xel-Ha Water Park, book it through the hotel, they will pick you up in an Air-Conditioned Bus, very pleasant. Once again the Fairmont Mayakoba is a top notch hotel, and that is where I will stay the next time I visit the Yucatan.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful resort, wonderful experience”
Reviews.Author: mercerdkny
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just returned from a week at the Fairmont Mayakoba and we loved it. From the moment we entered the property and saw the mangroves, we knew it was a special place. Take the boat cruise and ride the bikes through the property. We booked the resort last minute and stay at the Fairmont Level (lowest cost) room. Perfectly fine to meet our needs. I do wish the room had a mini sofa rather than two chairs. The flat screen TV was a plus although the choice of channels was suprisingly limited. Room was very clean and the housekeeping service was top level. Coffee and fridge in the room. The water bottles were plentiful. We ate at the mexican (mid priced) resturant two nights and for lunch. Great food and reasonable prices. We had a few lunches at the resturant by the beach - reasonable and very good. The beach is not a the main focus of the property. It was very hot when we were there so we stayed at the adult pool and main pool. Stunning pools. Service was very good at the pool. We were disappointed that we had pay for use of the gym ($10 a day). This resort is best for couples and older adults. Kids were around but it was not as kid friendly as other resorts. It does have a conference center and there were two conferences while we were there. Not an issue for us, the property is so big that it never felt crowded. I could see how some people would find this a problem, we did not. Mayakoba is a development, so I think there will be a few resorts that will share some facilities. It would be nice to have other resturants nearby to try. The trip to Playa del Carmen is $16 each way, so it can add up. We've been to other Fairmonts and stayed a other 4 to 5 star hotels, we think Mayakoba ranks among the best resorts we've been to.

Reviews.Title: “bad experience”
Reviews.Author: herherhu
Reviews.Content: My family and I were not treated politely by a gentlmen in reception when we arrived. It is very uncomfortable to fly cross country with small children and arrive at a "first class" resort tired, hungry, and be denied the rooms that were booked. I can probably deal with the fact that the rooms are not available, if it is said in a polite manner. I also thought that we would be compensated for the trouble and hardship that this individual buy the name of Cristobal caused my familiy and myself, but we were not compensated in any way whatsoever. On the contrary, it was a very expensive and uncomfortable stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba for us unfortunatly.. We planned this vacation for months and decided on the Fairmont Mayakoba but I really regret staying there. I asked to talk to the manager in charge at the time that I arrived to explain the problem that I had, but this person at the front desk claimed that he was the manager and that I could not talk to anybody else about the matter. I am sorry to say that these kind of individuals can ruin a business in seconds!

Reviews.Title: “Stay Here on Biz, Not Pleasure”
Reviews.Author: Bond,James
Reviews.Content: Stay here for business where your company is picking up the tab. Not for pleasure. In fact, I don't think the hotel is geared towards leisure customers as a business model. Not a criticism, just a fact. Pros are tranquility, privacy, nice fairly private beach. Staff is certainly helpful when available. Everyone was nice and went out of the way - again when available. Problem comes when the concierge is unavailable for half-our (phone keeps ringing, so you stop trying). Do be aware of the travel agency. They skim. I noticed but let it go. Only $10. You definitely feel nickel/dimed. Again not a problem if your company is paying. Food was definitely good at La Laguna. Breakfast at hotel lobby was quite unremarkable. Be prepared to pay up. Gym was fantastic. That said, we stayed at Secrets Capri previously. Our first all-inclusive vacation. We were skeptical - but blown away. May not have the cachet of a Fairmont, but they deliver (only downside was the dinners, nothing gourmet). Places like Fairmont have to pick up their game for the prices charged. All-inclusive hotels are changing the rules.

Reviews.Title: “Pros and Cons at this Resort!”
Reviews.Author: PassionForTravel42
Reviews.Content: Overall, a very nice resort. We traveled with 2 small children, ages 4 and 6. The rooms and physical facilities were beautiful, some of the nicest we have stayed in. They were spacious and very tastefully decorated. The Kids Center was outstanding. The hotel has a corporate focus. There were pros and cons to this. It seemed very quiet most of the time as most guests were at conference rooms and activities. This made it easy to get beach chairs, get restaurant reservations, etc., but it was also a bit odd to feel like you were one of the few people actually on vacation. I would say overall this was a positive, but it did lose the intimacy of a smaller resort. The restaurants were just okay. We never had a bad meal but never had a great meal. A small convenience store on sight was nice for light snacks and meals. Overall, prices for food were what we would expect for a resort. But drinks were extremely expensive. As a bonus, kids under 5 ate free. My biggest disappointment was that I did not know the property for the most part is situated away from the beach. To protect the environment, the hotel and major restaurants had to be built in the mangrove swamps. Canals ran through the property which were quite charming. To get to the beach and approximately 10% of rooms actually located on the beach, you had to take a golf cart or boat. While the golf carts ran frequently, this was an inconvenience. Overall, since most of the facilities were located inland, we felt like we were at a jungle resort vs. a beach resort. Had I realized this was the way the property was set up, I would perhaps not have been as disappointed about the lack of beach presence during the majority of the time. We also found service above average, but not outstanding. They made an effort, but seemed to often fall just short at times. We enjoyed day trips from the hotel to Mayan ruins at Coba and Tulum and Xcaret park. If we were to return to the area, we would seek out slightly better properties, recognizing that there is a good chance we would end up back at the Fairmont. So...pros and cons. Overall, a great trip!

Reviews.Title: “Definitely Overrated”
Reviews.Author: bls213
Reviews.Content: We just stayed at the Fairmont Mayakoba last week. How they received a AAA Five Diamond award is beyond comprehension. First, the front desk staff is disorganized and definitely not customer service oriented. Our room was not ready even after the official check-in time of 3:00 pm. They actually gave us a tacky beeper that would buzz us when the room was ready! Then, we were given a double bed room, even though we had confirmation, in writing, that we were to receive a King bed room. Our package included a $250 F&B credit but upon check-out, it was not applied and we had to fight for it. There were other guests disputing false phone charges so you really must review your bill with a fine tooth comb or you will get ripped off!!!! We were very disappointed with the physical property. First, you cannot view the ocean or beach from the main part of the property so you feel like you're in the middle of a Disney park...or in Arizona. To get to the beach requires a golf cart ride, definitely not convenient. Their were many areas of the property that were not well-maintained and were already showing wear and tear. Rooms did not feel really clean and didn't smell fresh. The food was OK, but nothing extraordinary. The wait staff was friendly and appeared to be trying so they were an upgrade over the front desk staff! During our stay, there were a couple of large groups so it appears they cater to this type of business...lots of small kids and babies too (so annoying to deal with crying babies when trying to relax at the pool). The nicest restaurant was closed one evening for a group dinner! On the positive side, the spa is very nice and our treatments there were great. We would not return to this hotel and we will not recommend it to others.

Reviews.Title: “This Hotel Is a Ripoff and Full of Crooks”
Reviews.Author: corpfinman
Reviews.Content: We were at Fairmont Mayakoba from April 1-6, 2008. The hotel is full of "dollar vultures" and crooks. Do not trust anyone at the hotel. We were charged for things that we did not use -- valet parking. Our hotel room was fully paid for via Apple Tours but they still levied charges adding up to hundreds of dollars in resort fees, etc. We rented a car for a day from the hotel premises (Carlos -- he is the guy who sits in the travel agency in the hotel) and we were asked to pay in US dollars in cash and then our credit card was also charged for $86.75. He refused to give us any receipt for the cash payment and then took an imprint of our credit card to boot. He then used the credit card imprint to charge us again. He realized this when we returned to the US. FULL OF CROOKS. DO NOT GO TO THIS HOTEL. The rooms are nothing to write home about. We were in room 609 it was far from everything. The food in the restaurants are way, way overpriced $$$$$$$$$!!! This is extortion at best. We felt like captive victims in the premises with our US dollars there for the taking by the folks who run this place. You are better off staying at a different hotel and taking the cab to downtown Playa for meals etc. Clutch your wallet tight if you dare to stay here and DO NOT TRUST THE CAR RENTAL GUY named CARLOS and BUYER BEWARE IN GENERAL.

Reviews.Title: “Fairmont Luxury and privacy”
Reviews.Author: Redee2Run
Reviews.Content: We are a married couple who belong to the Fairmont frequent guest program, but we paid for our room at Mayakoba. We stayed in a casita suite (Room 802) with a private rooftop pool and butler. Mauricio was the most wonderful, intuitive and gracious assistant! You must ask for him! Every idea we had was immediately arranged by him. He seemed genuinely concerned with making our stay as perfect as possible. Nothing was beyond his ability to please. He is a true gentleman. Our rooftop pool overlooked the beachfront pool, so we had a wonderful view but lots of privacy, too. We never saw or heard any of the other guests in their rooftop pools. The other side of our casita overlooked the lagoon, so we could watch the sunset. Yes, it is a long way from the main lobby to the beach. Yes, the resort is huge and a little difficult to navigate on foot (and especially at night) but we never waited for a golf cart. When we were ready to leave we would pick up the phone and a golf cart would be at our door within in 10 minutes. We took a 10 minute, $20 taxi into Playa Del Carmen for a couple of evenings just to walk around and see the crowds. It's easy and safe. Some tips: Beachfront casitas with private pools are very luxurious, too, but had little outside privacy. There is no need to rush to the pool and "claim" your chairs early in the morning - there are plenty of pools and chairs. The palapas on the beach were very large and kept us comfortably in the shade. All of the staff are eager to assist you in any way they can. Don't be afraid to ask if you need something. Special mention: Nicolas who is in charge of the Front Desk is a very special person - a throwback to the days of GRAND HOTLELS and the men who managed them. He is wise beyond his years, and a very gracious host. He juggled special requests with speed, agility and a smile on his face, always. While we were there a large group had their Presidents Club meeting, but we did not feel neglected by the staff at the restaurants. Las Brisas Terrace does serve the best burger and fish sandwiches I've ever tasted. El Puerto served very elegant and delicious fresh food. We ate an a la carte breakfast at la Laguna which was also very good. We saw mostly couples at the resort, although there seemed to be a few families with young children and they seemed to enjoy themselves. I would highly recommend this resort. I only regret that we didn't use the spa facilites.

Reviews.Title: “Great experience for a family of four at Spring Break”
Reviews.Author: well-travelledmom
Reviews.Content: Our experience was really great. The Mayakoba was amazing for a family with kids! I definitely think the accommodation we had --Signature Casita's with the Royal Service (private butler) in the Playa area--are worth it and the way to go. Mariana--our butler--followed us around and made reservations for all meals and tours. She was excellent. It was really convenient. We arrived with no plans and she really helped us. Also, the accommodation we had was perfect for us as a family. We had privacy--the master suite has doors-- and the sleeper sofa in the living room was fine for the girls (ages 10 and 6); they had ample space and their own bath and closet space. Also, the private plunge pool on the roof that this accommodation comes with was fun and decadent. The decks outside our casita were beautiful with views of the Mangroves and on the roof (in the pool) a sea view. You feel like you are in your own little house. The hotel's beach was great and the pools were really nice. The service was friendly and there was no bad attitude. Overall, the service was really good for the Caribbean or for anywhere. They couldn't bring you enough fresh towels and the beach food service, drinks, etc. was plentiful and quick. The help did not stand around always waiting for a tip and were grateful when they received one. Everyone was happy and smiling, eager to talk to you. We had a babysitter two nights named Natalia--who was outstanding. The girls asked for her the 2nd night. The kids club was pretty nice and had some good programs, although the girls only used it one morning. Although at capacity the resort did not seem crowded.
