However, the atmosphere is very romantic. The all day food menu for the beach/pool side is great. Burgers, salads, club sandwiches, spring rolls, etc. Prices average about $20 per item. I found the service on the beach and by the pool to be fantastic, efficient. I noticed other reviewers indicated very poor, slow service, this wasn't my exeperience. Finally, the El Lobby Lounge - - we had drinks and appetizers here and it was a beautiful experience. We sipped our drinks and ate as we overlooked lagoons and watched the sunset. Appetizers are well priced at $5 each (small) and the selection is very good. Drinks however run about $12-$15 each. For incidentals there is a cafe/store near La Laguna - - this sells books, magazines, sunscreens, drinks, cookies, muffins, sandwiches, chips, cigarettes, coffee, etc. There is also a store downstairs in the main building (next to El Puerto) which sells typical hotel gifts and clothes (expensive, weird clothes and jewelry). However, they also sell books and cigarettes and a few other incidentals. The grounds of this hotel are just beautiful. The bathroom in the lobby is stunning. There are three pools on the property. The first near the lobby and the block we stayed in is lovely. However, when you see the pool in the middle of the grounds it pales in comparison. This pool is huge and stunning. It has a kids area, an adult only area and a swim-up bar. The pool is massive and has little nooks and areas where you set up for the day and just relax in a chair. The third pool, located by the beach is wonderful. The view at the end of the pool overlooking the beach is paradise. The beach itself is SPECTACULAR. The sand is bright white and feels like velvet. The water is incredible shades of turquoise, greens, and blues. The salt content must have been very high as we were quite buoyant. Although it is quite spread out, walking from the main building to the middle (La Laguna and main pool) is only a five minute walk. However, from there to the beach it's probably about another 15 minute walk - - one we never did. Golf carts are abundant and always stop to offer rides, are also available immediately from designated points - - we never had to wait more than 30 seconds for a ride. Drivers are safe and very friendly. We had two outside excursion tours, one to Chichen Itza and the other to Xcaret. The drive to Chicken Itza from the Mayakoba was about three hours each way. We went by tour bus and it was relatively painless. We took a taxi to Xcaret which is only about 15 minutes down the road. They charged us $25 USD each way. We spent an afternoon in Playa del Carmen, the cab was $15 USD each way. Only about 10-15 minutes down the road. We ate at a terrible restaurant and walked along looking at the shops - - most of them selling the same wares. Each time it was a pleasure to return to the hotel. The hotel was definitely not full to capacity, however, it did not feel like a ghost town, it felt intimate and romantic. On the second to last day of our trip a conference of about 400 people arrived. Although there were notably more people around, it didn't really impact services or space in a negative way. The service in the restaurants, housekeeping, and in general was wonderful. The staff are friendly and helpful. We never had any problems with theft (as per other reviewers). Would definitely stay again - - our experience was very positive.

Reviews.Title: “Underwhelming”
Reviews.Author: leharvey
Reviews.Content: I had heard rave reviews from co-workers about the Fairmont Mayakoba and (unfortunately) did not do additional research on the property before planning our conference there -- I am just very thankful that none of us were robbed-- especially since we brought our top clients there with us! After all was said and done, I was pretty underwhelmed by the experience... On the positive side: - the weather was beautiful - the beach and pools were well-maintained and never crowded (since everyone there also seemed to be there for a conference) - the conference center had enough capacity to cater to our large crowd - the property was easily accessible fom the airport and was just 15mins outside Playa del Carmen - the staff thought of little details such as bringing bug spay for guests to use at night events On the negative side: - the property was massive - it was a 15 min walk to the beach from most rooms - very poor signage...I got lost several times wandering through the property trying to find my room as signs were often either lacking or ambiguous. This problem was even worse at night! - the service at the restaurants was HORRIBLE. It literally took us at least 2 hours to eat lunch each day since we had to ask for everything multiple times before receiving it (if it ever ended up coming at all...) There are 4 more resorts going up in the same area as the Fairmont...my advice is to hold out for them! They are being built by companies (such as the Mandarin) that know how to run a resort properly.

Reviews.Title: “The perfect vacation!”
Reviews.Author: ND96
Reviews.Content: My husband and I have just returned from a week at Mayakoba (5/5 – 5/11), and we had an amazing experience, so wonderful that I feel I was at a completely different resort than the others who have posted recently. Apologies in advance for the length, but I wanted to touch on as much as I could.... About us: we are in our early 30s and both are professionals. We were looking for a great beach, quiet relaxation, golf, and great service. Arrival: Upon arrival, we immediately were greeted by staff with cold towels and water and escorted into the gorgeous open-air lobby, while staff tended to our luggage. One staff member took care of us exclusively after check in, showing us around and then taking us to our casita by golf cart, while explaining the property. Our luggage arrived by separate golf cart a short 5 minutes later. T The Rooms: we stayed in a private signature casita (the 800 series of casitas), which was at the beach (but not directly on the beach – they are the row of casitas directly behind the beach front suites if you look at the property map). Our room was beautifully appointed with a deck overlooking the lagoon. The room was immaculate, amenities including robes and slippers were replaced each day, and turndown service was excellent each evening. Additionally, whenever we had a request from housekeeping, the staff responded promptly. We kept iPods, money, passports, wallets locked in the room safe and didn’t have any problems. The beach casitas are perfectly located if you want to be near the beach, the beach infinity pool and the bar at Las Brisas. While they are set apart (significantly) from the lobby and the main pool area, we enjoyed the privacy and never had a problem getting to and fro when needed. There are bikes aplenty throughout the property, which we rode often. It’s a five minute ride from the beach to the main pool (and adult infinity pool) and the restaurant La Laguna and Café Maya. It is a few minutes longer to the main lobby and spa. Also, if you are not inclined to bike, there is always a golf cart to take you wherever you are going. You also can arrange golf cart service in advance if you need to be somewhere at specific time. We had to be in the lobby one morning by 6:45 for our Alltournative zip-line tour (HIGHLY recommended, by the way), and we called the night before to have a cart pick us up at 6:30 with no problems. My husband did the same for his tee time at El Cameleon – he was taken to the lobby and then driven to the club house. The beach: We spent most of our time at the beach and the beach pool, as it was so close to our casita. The beach is gorgeous (albeit windy in the afternoon) and was never overly crowded while we were there. There are ample umbrellas and palapas if you want to stay out of the sun. We found the beach service to be impeccable; there always was a staff member to bring us down to the beach with towels, set up our chairs and umbrellas, and send over a waiter for food and drink service. Likewise, the food and drink service was excellent and timely. There is quite a bit of beach for the staff to cover, so we understood that there might be a wait for our drinks, although we never remarked that it was taking too long. Our experience with the staff on the beach was top notch – they were solicitous and friendly - helpful with anything we needed. We felt the same at the beach pool, where we spent almost each late afternoon. The staff even got us an ice bucket for our coronas that we had brought from the room. The adult infinity pool is great if you want quiet, and the chairs have fabulous cushions so you can hang out, sleep, or enjoy the view of the lagoon for hours. There is a great lunch menu offered poolside, as well as fresh fruit and cold towels. Service was excellent. The main pool is beautiful with so many different areas that you almost never run into other guests. There are also cabana-type tents you can sit under (and umbrellas) to avoid too much sun. The restaurants: La Laguna: We ate four meals here; one dinner, one dinner at the bar, one buffet breakfast and one breakfast off the menu. For each, the service again was efficient and friendly and the food was very good (and VERY reasonably priced – I actually was shocked at how good and diverse the menu was for the price). Las Brisas – the restaurant: We had one dinner in the Las Brisas dining room, which was excellent. It is the resort’s more elegant restaurant, and no beach attire, shorts, open-toed shoes (men) are allowed. The service was french-style; very attentive but unobtrusive. The menu is relatively small but the food (diver scallops, grouper, Cornish game hen) was excellent, the wine selection was good, and dessert was amazing. Our only complaint was that the live music (a small jazz band with a piano player) was a bit too loud at our original table, but the hostess promptly gave us a new table and it was fine. While the Las Brisas dining room is the most expensive restaurant at the resort, it was no more expensive than a comparable restaurant here in Boston. Las Brisas – Outside bar and restaurant: We ate several times at the bar/terrace outside at Las Brisas and found the service attentive and efficient and the bartenders fantastic. The food (pulled pork with jicama slaw, burgers and truffle fries, ahi tuna fresh rolls, chips and guacamole) was great and we never waited more than 10 minutes. Prices were very reasonable - ahi rolls were about $8 and the pulled pork sandwich was about $15 - nothing out of the ordinary for a resort. Café Maya: We visited the Café several times for Gatorade, water, turkey sandwiches (which were great), chips, etc. It’s perfect for a quick “to go” bite and for drinks to bring to the pool or beach. We didn’t eat at El Puerto, but it looked nice. We loved the lobby bar, which has great service, drinks and tapas. We also used room service twice and it was fine. Because of our location at the beach, it did take about 40 minutes. Willow Stream Spa: Our massages were great. The locker rooms are exquisite, with steam and sauna rooms and a whirlpool. There’s a “relaxation room” on the second floor of the spa, where you can hang out before or after your services, and they offer muffins, freshly squeezed juices, and coffee and teas. The spa also has two mineral pools that are only for the use of spa guests. They are on the second floor – on the roof, essentially. This was a great place to spend a few hours unwinding, as it was virtually deserted. Gym: Could be larger, given the size of the resort, but it was fine for the 2-3 times I used it. Access is complimentary if you are a Fairmont President’s Club member. Golf: The course is gorgeous but it has A LOT of water, so bring extra balls. The only complaint is that there is a fair amount of construction going on (the other resorts are going up in the Mayakoba complex) and my husband said it was somewhat distracting on some of the holes. Checkout was smooth – we were picked up at our casita and our luggage arrived in the lobby separately (and promptly). Other Observations: 1.It appears that a fair amount of reviewers of this property visited for conferences, sales rewards trips or for other work-related reasons. We noticed that there were three such groups staying at the Fairmont while we were there. If you are considering this property for a vacation that is in no way work-related, I would avoid relying on those types of reviews because a business traveler’s needs and concerns generally diverge from a vacationing family, couple, etc. Our observations were that the few people we heard complaining were at the resort as part of a conference or company event of some kind and their complaints followed suit [ie. rooms too far from conference areas, organized events/dinners not as nice as they’d hoped, expensive and spotty WiFi access]. I think expectations (and mind set) may be different based on your reason for being at the resort. 2.We went into Playa del Carmen twice (once to Wal-Mart to get bottled water, cheese & crackers, and Coronas for the room) and once to dinner at Yaxche (which was amazing!). We had planned to eat in PDC more often, because of the reviews we had read re: the high prices & lack of quality of the food at the resort, but that simply wasn’t our experience, and we found that once the evening rolled around, we didn’t feel like leaving. Also, we didn’t love what little we saw of PDC (Yaxche notwithstanding). Ultimately, we had the greatest vacation and will return as soon as possible (even though I am tempted to try the Mandarin Oriental when it opens in the fall!). We were so well-taken care of by the staff that I think better service would be hard to find. I do think you need to know going in that it’s a quiet place - and it’s not a typical “ocean resort” where everything is on the beach (and if that is what you are looking for, go elsewhere). But if you want a beautiful, natural environment and “quiet time,” we thought it was perfect.

Reviews.Title: “First Class Operation! Loved it!”
Reviews.Author: Cuse1
Reviews.Content: My wife and I ust got back yesterday from a 5 night stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba. Our time there was wonderful! The rooms are huge -- especially the beautiful bathrooms which have a double sink, seperate lavatory room, a soaking tub and an enormous shower. We were in the 500 section which is approximately in the middle of the resort near the main pool area. I've read some of the other reviews about waiting 30 minutes for a golf cart (why would you do that when it doesn't take more than 15 minutes to walk anywhere) to pick you up and have to say we did not experience that. The carts ran constantly We actually walked most of the time both to the beach and to the lobby/convention center area. The resort also has mountain bikes available at all tram stops which can be used for free to get around and a boat system. The staff are very polite and eager to be of service. The grounds are beautiful. We loved the infinity edge pool by the ocean. The gym at the spa has high end workout equipment and was usually almost empty when I went. Only downsides were about half of the people in our party came down with the stomach flu although I'm sure it happened off the resort. The food was just OK. The breakfast buffet's could have been better. Drinks were very high priced. The beach was also really windy - think sandblasting. I have never been to Cancun before so I'm not sure if that's common or not. Despite a few minor shortcomings I would strongly recommend this resort!

Reviews.Title: “huge property lacking service”
Reviews.Author: josebda
Reviews.Content: i stayed at the Mayakoba for 3 nights attending a conference, May 6th -9th the trek to my casita was over 2 bridges down a path past the golf course and meandering thru the mangrove jungle and then arrived at my casita, my casita was a one bedroom beachfront one with its own plunge pool on the beach, too bad that i did not have the time to enjoy it as i had scheduled workshops and functions all day until late at night.the butler did show up and offered his services the room was beautiful, with its living room guest bath, huge bedroom, and awesome masterbath bath loved the glass enclosed shower feature that made you feel you were outside in the jungle with the vegetation only problem with being this far away from the main complex was that only means of transport was to walk at night was creepy as the iguanas crossed the path and scared the daylights out of me, of course your in the tropics so there are insects....was bitten at an outdoor fucntion by mosquitos daytime walk was too hot and sweaty by the time i got to the main building) ride a bike, same thing hot and sweaty dressed in business attire for a function or call and wait for the buggy golfcart to shuttle yuo back and forth , i soon learnt that one needs a 15 min window to get from the beach to the main building. one night friends came by to visit and enjoy the pool when we called for the cart it took 20 mins to show up...there was a slight smell of burning garbage in the morning as i guess with the on going construction next door on the beach they may have been burning garbage on that site, needless to say it was not pleasant to smell first thing in the am sure wished thet had LED alram clocks as they have alram clocks were battery operated and did not glow in the dark, the ac turned itself off in the middle of the night and i woke up in a sweat and had to turn it on again ! checkout was chaotic as the baggage cart was making its rounds collecting luggage and when it did arrive our bags were not on the cart after we were told they were, so another 10 mins for the baggage to arrive. suggest that the have a stocked minibar in the room , you need to call and have your beer, wine etc delivered to the room it costs $20 US a day for internet access if you enroll and become a Fairmont Gold member the internet access is FREE also they lock and chain the bikes up at 6pm, sure wished they had someone check them as i tried to get onto 3 bikes and each had a flaw, either the chain was off the sprokett , brakes didnt work or the seat was loose.....

Reviews.Title: “Nice resort but poor service”
Reviews.Author: Tango&Luna
Reviews.Content: I just returned from a short stay and the reviews are accurate: while the property is beautiful, the service is lacking and non-attentive. Rooms are comfortable, good size and nice bathrooms. I would certainly recommend the Casitas - although you have to be ready to accept that most rooms do not face the ocean. The main issue: poor service and lack of attention to details! The alarm clock was missing batteries, they missed a wake-up call, check-in lacked any sincere welcome and 25 minutes after I had been escorted to the room with my luggage staff came knocking asking if I had found my luggage (staff seemed confused at all times). I was attending meetings and service in the banquet rooms was poor - one had to flag staff and permanentky ask them for everything: soft drinks, coffee refills, etc. The public bathrooms had no soap or soap dispensers. While it is a nice property, because of the service short falls I would certainly not return for a vacation.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice resort that just needs to hire a few more waitstaff”
Reviews.Author: travelinman3
Reviews.Content: Beautiful facility, great pools, beautiful beach, gorgeous surroundings, rooms were spacious and the bathrooms were special. Lunch at the restaraunt by the beach took better than 2 hours one day, no waitstaff at the amazing pool by the beach was disapointing. This place could significanlty increase its revenue by having waitstaff available to take the drink orders that many patrons want to place. I saw a number of people get frustrated, go to the local store and fill a cooler or two with beer. They are losing a mint by not having the neccessary staff.

Reviews.Title: “Don't Believe The Negative Reviews”
Reviews.Author: iclaudius69
Reviews.Content: I just got back from a 5 nite stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba. I read all the reviews herein and was a tad nervous considering the amount of negative feedback, but it turned out to be completely unwarranted. Yes, it's the Fairmont -- so it is $17 USD for two litres of water and $55 for breakfast. It's expensive, no doubt. Rediculously expensive in fact, but not suprising. It ain't a Super 8. Service = average. They do try. Food = average. Certainly nothing breathtaking. Grounds = gorgeous. Yes, it's big, but not daunting. Golf cart service is quick and efficient. Beach = gorgeous. NOT small or dirty as described in the reviews herein. Rooms = nice. Stone shower, a/c worked, no complaints. $15 USD cab ride to Playa for cheaper everything (Playa to my surprise was expensive) All in all -- I had a blast. The place is beautifully maintained and if you can afford it will prove to be a good time.

Reviews.Title: “They Lie - Go somewhere else”
Reviews.Author: Mr.Smart&Final
Reviews.Content: The lobby is over 1 mile to the beach!!! They show a nice drawing showing the beach nearby but that isn't correct. The service and accomodations were C grade while paying an A+ price ...beware The rooms smell like mold! The bedding too! The resort is located in a man made lagoon ....opt for an all inclusive resort that is ON THE BEACH or you will be sorry Husbands, you will get grief thoughout the entire trip if you stay here.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful facilities, but service is lacking!”
Reviews.Author: jc9276
Reviews.Content: I was recently a guest of the hotel for 4 days during a company awards trip. The aesthetics of the grounds, buildings, restaurants, pools, and spa are all fantastic. The rooms were large and well-appointed. Service was my main source of frustration the entire trip. After having an exceedingly nice reception by the lobby staff including a brief tour of the area and a staff member who personally walked me to my casita, the service went downhill from here. Specifically, the poolside watistaff and bartenders were unattentive and unusually slow even when you finally were acknowleged. Lunch took 2.5 hours one day, finally arriving after 2 or 3 reminders. No one would actually come around the pool to wait on guests regularly. You were forced to either walk to the bar for drinks or ask the bartender to send someone out to wait on you. When you did finally get some attention, the staff seemed annoyed or put out that you had requests. Disappointing. Housekeeping, which is touted to be twice daily, sometimes showed up for their one-time visit around 5pm, as we were just coming in from the pool or beach. I spent a couple days sitting outside while they finished up the room. Once I stepped inside, linens/towels were not consistently replaced and never were any toiletry items replaced. I would normally not complain, but come on....this resort is supposed to be on par with Four Seasons and Ritz Carlton. The Fairmont Mayakoba has much to overcome in the service arena to compare to that caliber. On a positive note, the spa service, environment, and staff were superb. The restaurants were decent, but again, not on par with other resorts in this pricepoint.

Reviews.Title: “Relaxing Experience”
Reviews.Author: Abbystravels
Reviews.Content: The Mayakoba is a large and beautiful resort. The staff was very friendly and accomodating. The Spa treatments were wonderful (especially the East Meets West hot stone treatment). Delicious food was hard to come by - the only restaurant serving decent food on the property was the El Puerto restaurant. I would have given the resort 5 stars if the food were better. When you visit take the leisurely boat ride to the beach as it is quite a hike down to the water. If the boat is not available, definitely ride the bikes down. The rooms were spacious, the beds very comfortable. The taxi rides into Playa Del Carmen took less than 15 minutes at a cost of $150 Pesos and that included tip. Plenty of pools for everyone and you could always find a spot - nothing like the all inclusive places where you have to get up at the crack of dawn to reserve a space for the day. Mayakoba is definitely a place I would recommend if you are interested in relaxation as well as proximity to plenty of nightlife.

Reviews.Title: “Great place & surroundings but regular service.”
Reviews.Author: Viajero46
Reviews.Content: Our stay at Fairmont Mayakoba was a bit dissapointing, my wife and I were expecting a lot more from our first experience in this so called luxurious resort that, on paper and in the reality, looked great, but great surroundings and rooms must be complemented with good service. As experienced travelers and having stayed in other similar resorts in Mexico, like Las Brisas in Acapulco and Fiesta Americana Grand in Los Cabos, we were taken by surprise with all the small details and extra costs that made our stay a little unpleasant. As we rented a car for the week our first surprise was the daily USD $ 13 charge for parking, which after paying almost $ 400 a night for the stay, one could think that this small charge could had been included, but no. Another thing we did not like was that the mini-bar at the room was empty and had to be filled, and paid for in advance, if you wanted to have something to drink in your room, so it was similar to room service. I had to plan what I would like to drink in my room for the next five days and pay for it ! Finally the service was uneven, one broken WC in our room took 4 hours to get attention from the maintenance staff, the front desk staff was arrogant, nothing to compare with the staff in the Farimont Waterfront in Vancouver, BC. By contrast the waiters and service staff at the different restaurants & beach, the bellboys, with them the service was excellent ! The hotel was completely full but this should not be an excuse for the regular service received for the rate paid. We will look for other resorts before coming back to this specific hotel, which still needs time to be at the same level of the other Fairmont resorts and similar rate hotels in México. Hope they get it.

Reviews.Title: “Dissapointed”
Reviews.Author: worldtravel007
Reviews.Content: Recently spent a week in this resort. On the one hand the property is quite beautiful, the spa is first class, and the employees aim to please. On the other hand, the service and the food are not up to par. The employees are all very nice but surprisingly, the service in all the restaurants is incredibly slow and the food was "inferior". Be prepared to wait 40 minutes to be served once you order even if the restaurant is empty. I say surprisingly because our experience in other hotels in Mexico has been superior. There are problems with other types of service too. As an example, our key system failed one night and we were locked out. Called everyone but It still took the hotel over one hour and a half to fix the problem. Make sure you store your valuables in the safe. My in laws almost had their camera and computer stolen. He walked in as the "individuals" were ready to walk out with the equipment. Contrary to what's claimed in the hotels website, the hotel does not have any water sports. The tennis courts were inaugurated the week we arrived. It can easily take 20 minutes to get there from your room. Playa del Carmen is a good 20 minutes away so if you are interested in visiting the town be ready for the taxi rides.

Reviews.Title: “Superb”
Reviews.Author: Daoda
Reviews.Content: Beautiful property about 20 minutes from Playa del Carmen. (When I´d mention to any local in Cancun or Playa del Carmen that we were staying here, they´d always comment about what a nice hotel it was.) Close enough so you can easily go into town for dinner or bar hopping but quiet when you want to go to sleep. Beds were amazingly soft, very hard to find in Mexico even at American chain hotels. Aveda amendities, lovely furnishings, accomodating and efficient staff. Clientele was generally professional families with kids, both Mexican and North American; sometimes a bit snooty, but the staff put up with it well. It´s a 15 minute walk to the beach from the main lobby and rooms unless you have a cabana on the beach, but there´s always a golf cart available to shuttle you back and forth. You can even take a boat through the jungle. Food, of course, was expensive, but that´s to be expected. If you´re the kind of person who would normally stay at a Fairmont property (The Plaza, Banff Springs, etc.), then you´ll love this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “A fantastic experience!”
Reviews.Author: TheExploringCanucks1
Reviews.Content: We just came back from our most memorable family trip ever. The resort is simply fantastic. We found the staff to be extremely pleasant and very helpful - they really helped make the trip special. When we needed something there was almost always someone nearby who was very helpful to us and our children (6 and 1). I have to admit that we were somewhat worried after having read some of the reviews posted by visitors who were at the property late last year and over the holiday season, but it would seem to me that the management team and staff have successfully solved most, if not all, of the problems that were mentioned. We found the food quality to be good to excellent, although the portions were very large by our standards. Yes, the prices are somewhat of a premium, but it is a top quality resort. The gardens and the lagoons are tended to fantastically. When you think about the work that goes into keeping such a large property up it is truly amazing. The property is stunning and well tended to - and the beach is tremendous. Althought the hotel was full, or close to it, we never had to worry about chairs or towels. Walks with our children around the resort were very enjoyable - and transportation was easily at hand if required. Note: many people wait around for transportation...yet the walks are not as long as they might appear and are very enjoyalbe. From the reception to the beach it is about 15 minutes, maybe 20 if you have kids or take it very slowly. Playa is a short distance away and supplies like diapers, beach toys and so on can be had at Walmart or a host of Mexican supermarkets. There are some nice restaraunts in town as well. A couple of small things...the hotel room floors are slippery when wet so be careful...and don't expect a lot of nightlife (which was perfect for us!). You may want to try some of the Mexican wines (there are a couple on the lists - along with many others from around the world) and they are surprisingly nice.

Reviews.Title: “great time at a great place”
Reviews.Author: cappyNewYork
Reviews.Content: We just got back from a week of relaxation at a beautiful place.I was very nervous about staying at the Mayakoba because of some of the reviews that I have read.We actually almost checked out after the first night and we were glad we didn't.We arrived late in the afternoon and we were overwhelmed at the size of the resort the main lobby to the beach is 1 and 1/2 miles away.We stayed at one of the beach rooms (800 grouping) which is very close to the beach which turned out good for us since we are beach people.The beach section is called the private section and they charge a little more for the rooms since you are litterally seperated by a 1/4 mile of jungle that they left there except for a path to walk or use a golf cart or bike.It seemed all of our fears were comming true big resort,hard to get around and on top of that the couple next to us checked in with a baby that kept on crying. We asked the hotel to move us and we decided that if it wasn't going to easy we would switch to another hotel that we had tentative reservations if we needed them.The hotel responed quickly and offered us a choice of 3 rooms to choose from.Whithin a hour we picked a room and moved with the help of the staff all the private rooms are assigned a butler that keeps in touch with you since they know the main lobby is far away.The Butler also made all of our off premise reservations booked trips and delivered an agenda to us on the beach with all of the activities we booked for the day with phone numbers confirmation numbers and directions. It took one day to realize this was the place we were staying the staff was great the food was good we went off property for dinner except for one night and we were satisfied with the food and service. We had all of our other meals either beach side or one of the other restaraunts and the food was fine.the golf carts were always available and quite all electric no sound at all hardly.The only suggestion I would give people who are going if you are a pool family get your room around the pool area and venture out from thier if the beach is your thing stay by the beach they do have a pool their not that big and very quite and that is where the beachfront lounge and restaraunt is located.The only thing they do not serve breakfeast their so we picked up some fruit the night before and stayed at that end of the resort most of the time.The staff is amazing the hotel was almost sold out and after a day the people at the beach,pool and restaraunts new you and what you liked and it made a big resort feel comfortable and small.Enjoy your stay

Reviews.Title: “Pleasantly surprised”
Reviews.Author: skibums
Reviews.Content: Considering we're huge snow lovers, we were already bummed about losing valuable ski time for this trip, and the bad reviews had us totally dreading this trip. Imagine how thrilled we were to find most of our fears ungrounded! The grounds and the rooms are beautiful. The spa and the fitness facility were also quite nice. We have stayed in many resorts for corporate events and this would rank up among the top. (Last year we were at the Fairmont Acapulco Princess and everyone in our group agreed this was like night and day). We stayed in the 500 building of rooms on an upper floor, corner unit. We never experienced any problems with cart noises and guests going over the bridge. They must have replaced all the gas carts. The only noise issue was at 5 a.m. when they were pushing the carts ful of tableware and food over to the Isla lawn. Of course it was for our own group's morning event, but way too much rattling very early in the morning. Maybe they can put rubber mats on the carts to cut down on the noise. We thought the rooms were nicely appointed. In tropical places you really don't want a lot of rugs and heavy furniture. I would agree though, that a chaise lounge on each deck would be nice. Of course for your own relaxing, but also for more seating if you have guests come to your room. We were on the deck a lot and never had a problem with bugs. They definitely need more hangers in each closet. Bring cd's as they have a nice bose player in each room. The fridge really only keeps things cool, not cold - but our bellman told us that upfront and pointed out where the ice was if we wanted to get more. Quite a few of us did experience the "key issue" of not being able to get back in our rooms at various times and it usually took more time and hassle than was acceptable. At one point an employee happened by while I was waiting and let me into our room. While I was grateful, I was concerned that they never bothered to verify that I belonged to that room. As for the walk to the beach - the complainers must be major couch potatoes! At a leisurely pace it wasn't more than 10 minutes from the lobby and there was always a cart going by offering a ride. As we were there for a conference, all our food was buffet at our own event. But I will say none of us were happy with the food. No flavor and basically all the same texture. The only difference in taste was if it was hot or cold. There was no flavor to the salsa, guacamole, shrimp sauce - things you expect to have a "kick". A few people did take in lunch at the beach bar and that got better reviews for taste, but 2 hours for a lunch was the norm. Speaking of the beach, we thought it was fine - people need to keep in mind the amount of damage that was done by the hurricane if they're expecting "pristine" conditions. Overall we had a great time and with some tweaking here and there ( mostly in the food quality) this could definitey go from a 4 star to 5.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel and spa but rental car needed!”
Reviews.Author: Sue22
Reviews.Content: Just back from 6 nights at Mayakoba. Expected to be inconvenienced by the PGA golf tournament but it was a non-issue. The property is visually exquisite and nicely arranged. Others have said it's spread out and the beach is far from the main area, as if that's a negative! We chose this hotel because it's spread out. Yes you can take a golf cart, but we chose to walk everywhere. I used a bike once (they are all over the place, just grab one and go) but they are not in the best condition and hard to adjust for one's height. We loved the walks to and from the beach. Stayed in a deluxe casita (room # in the 300 range) and it was perfectly located near the main pool and breakfast location, as well as close to the spa. Our room was large and comfortable. The bathroom was extremely large with a tub overlooking a jungle scene (see photos). Bring your own essential oil and you will feel like you are in a spa! We had massages (just ok) which included use of the very relaxing hot pool upstairs (on an outside deck). They gave us free juice drinks (pineapple with chaya was the best one). Having a massage also gave us use of the steam room and aromatherapy room, lockers and showers. If you aren't having a service, then it costs $45 USD extra to use the facilities. The gym is $15 USD to use the equipment. Join the Fairmont President's Club, then it's free (and so is internet in the room). The beach has very nice sand. Try to get cushioned chairs, much more comfortable. We did not have to get there at 6am to mark our spot; could arrive at 11 or even 12 and get chairs, even during a school vacation week. The staff is friendly but it does take awhile to get your food order. Breakfast was a terrific deal - 190 pesos for cold buffet or 240 for hot buffet. I suggest choosing the buffet because it takes forever to get things if they are ordered from the kitchen. Buffet food was often replenished and the food quality was excellent. The choices were the same each morning but there was plenty to choose from. We had huge breakfasts, little snacks for lunch, then drove into Playa almost every night for dinner. Parking was not easy; we used one of two lots ($1 US per hour) located on Avenue 10 around Calle 2 and Calle 4, then walked down Fifth Avenue. We never once saw any free parking on the street. The concierge was pretty helpful in getting reservations, which i did through email about a month before our trip. We liked John Gray's Place (service was terrible but food was excellent), Negrosal (expensive but sophisticated), and Yaxche. I had read that the property is dark at night and to bring a flashlight; we never needed it. Housekeeping was 2x a day and thorough. The only thing to remember is to securely close your door; it won't fully close by itself unless you do it manually.....sometimes we found it open upon our return, but it was our own fault. This is not the best place to bring teenagers unless they have friends with them or really need to just rest by the beach or pool. There is not a lot of activity at either location. Our teens had homework to do and were happy to lounge most of the days when we stayed at the property. We took two field trips while there, which broke things up. We would definitely return to this lovely hotel again!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Loved it with a few flaws...”
Reviews.Author: TravelAgentJill
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed the 11th of Feb just for 2 nights as friends of ours were coming in on the 13th so we went to Cancun. The rooms are big and clean. We did have a leak however and the lamp made a spark when my husband tried turning it off. We called down to the front desk and they came up right away. The resort is a bit big for me but it is so pretty and clean. The staff is awesome and always asking how you are and if you need anything, The food and drinks were good but a bit high but hey it is a Fairmont so no complaints. Pools are awesome. I am a travel agent so I did recieve a awesome rate so cant complain at all. We did try to ask about a upgrade and was told no beach front casita's were available however we only saw 1 person in them the entire time we were there. Oh well.. Email me if you have any questions. jsliwa@carlsonwagonlit.com

Reviews.Title: “Interesting Experience- Not all Good/Not all bad”
Reviews.Author: sjben
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Fairmont Mayakoba Feb 10-17 2007. The property is beautiful and we definitely enjoyed ourselves. There are basically 2 sections of the hotel. The larger grouping of rooms are close to the lobby/spa/convention center and pools. The smaller grouping (about 40 or so rooms) are located near the beach. Some of these have plunge pools and roof top decks that overlook the ocean (like Las Ventanas). The few rooms that are on the beach directly overlook the hotel guests with beach chairs so, these are not as private. The ones on the back side with the rooftop pools or lower untils overlooking the river offer the most privacy. (These rooms are numbered 800 to 900.) The rooms are nice but missing some decorative detail as well as some of those touches one might see at a Four Seasons or other fine hotel such as fresh flowers in the room, dependable turn down service that includes a small token gift and/or a small welcome gi ft upon arrival, -chaise lounges on ones private deck instead of just chairs... My husband and I booked a room located at the beach area. We were close to the Las Brisas restaurant and there is an infinity pool overlooking the beach area as well. The wait staff helps with towels, drinks and one can eat lunch at the restaurant or the beach. I was told that they will be building 'Palapas' for shade on the beach instead of just umbrellas. Unlike some previous reviewers I thought the beach area was pretty. My husband and I took long walks in either direction and one can get a sense of the area and the other 3 resorts that will be part of Mayakoba ( The Banyan Tree, Viceroy and Rosewood). We were told by the staff that they will all be connected via the canals with boats already in use by the Fairmont. I would have been nice to receive some information in our room on the activities available to the guests. ie cooking classes, exersize classes and featured entertainment in the bars and restaurants. We did receive a Miami Herald delivered to our room daily which was nice. The Golf Course- El Camaleon surrounds entire property. My husband thought it was challenging and in 'great shape' -although it would have to be as the PGA tour is there this week. **Golf in the afternoon is available at a reduced rate and no one is on the course. As previous reviewers have suggested the food is nothing out of the ordinary. The taco buffet at La Laguna was very tasty. The restaurants in Playa Del Carmen that we tried were all very good though. Tips/Suggestions: 1. Rent a car - it is easy to get around. Playa is 20 min away and is based on a grid system- its easy to park most fimes for free and find shopping and restaurants. The main shopping street is 5th Avenue with the typical Mexican fare. If you have a car you can visit the ruins, Cozamel, Cancun etc... at your leisure. There is a travel agency in the Fairmont that can help with excursions. 2. Book a room near the beach (#'s800-900)- If you do in the AM get a golf cart back to the breakfast buffet at La Laguna, after breakfast stop at the nearby deli and purchase a sandwich, get a bike (usually outside the pool area or at the lobby) go back to the beach, store sandwiches and drinks in your in-room fridge and when the time is right- enjoy lunch on your private deck. The sandwiches are good quality and a better value than the food served at the beach. (The beach is 3/4 mile from the pool area /La Laguna so walking is possible but, takes longer. ) 3. If located at the beach - Call for a golf cart 10 min before you are ready to leave your oom. Call for your car ahead of time as well. Critiques: We did have some issues-- We were locked out of our room the first 3 nights after dinner. ( Since we were so far from the lobby it took some time for assistance). As it happens there were some issues with our door lock which eventually were resolved. Our room 'butler' never materialized, my husband did get sick from the food at one of the restaurants at the resort, the screen door in our room was broken, and light was out on the veranda, concierge forgot to confirm dinner reservations. So, on the 5th night of our stay we did complain to a manager and he did give us one night free lodging and the next day a butler delivered a formal apology with flowers and fruit. That did make us feel better about our stay. Unfortunatley, on the way home I realized that my brand new Ipod was missing from my bag. This was disturbing as I did not take it out of the room during my stay. However, I did not lock it in the safe while we were there and probably should have. (We have since made the hotel aware of the situation) All in all , The Fairmont property is attractive and the service was generally friendly and reliable. I feel that the price of the room (Private Signature Casita) catagory we stayed in though was not as good a value as some other hotels in the same catagory.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel and grounds- but it has its drawbacks”
Reviews.Author: Katieorange
Reviews.Content: My stay at the Mayakoba was pretty good. The landscape is absolutely breathtaking. But the shear size of the grounds can be overwhelming. The hotel is so large that there are 4 modes of transportation; foot, bike, golf cart or boat. From the lobby to the beach it takes about 20min by foot or 7min my golf cart. The team of staff is very nice, they all try to go the extra mile. (Only complaint--- we waited 2hrs for our luggage. And then another hour for Ice.—which is somewhat understandable because of the size of this property!) The rooms are absolutely gorgeous, great beds- Beautifully marbled bathrooms with a very modern Caribbean design. I would say value wise; I got a good deal on the room. I went for a conference so I only paid $250. But if I paid much more I wouldn’t feel the same way. The food at the hotel is very expensive! My sister and I split a hamburger, 2 cokes and 2 waters for $30usd. I probably wouldn’t return to the Mayakoba. While I think that Maya Rivera is much more adult than Cancun, I would prefer to stay at a all-inclusive resort. Lets Face it—All hotel grounds in Mexico are Grand, All of the staff works hard to accommodate, All of the food is mediocre.. So why not get drinks included!

Reviews.Title: “5 reasons to stay away”
Reviews.Author: saltyseaseeker
Reviews.Content: Brace yourself for the Mayakoba! It is as about un-Mexican as it gets. I love a luxury hotel but the Fairmont has created something devoid of warmth and charm and quite frankly, at $700 a night (cough), I expect more of an "experience". Alas, it was not to be. I traveled with my elderly mother who wanted a little r&r. She and I both love Mexico but after two nights in Tulum at a fancy eco hotel, I couldn't wait to get out of our Mayakobean nightmare. We left after one night. Yes they have Bose radios. Yes the bathrooms are handsome. Yes the staff is friendly (if somewhat over-coached). And yes the welcome iced tea and cool towel are a hopeful beginning. 5 Reasons I won't return: #1. Poorly planned. The idea of a waterway lagoon system seems cool but the reality is the "casitas" are front loaded geographically so that if you decide you want to wander over to the beach and have a drink to watch the sun sink into the horizon, you have to wait for a golf cart to pick you up. You may be waiting a while. FYI: Walking would be freakish at this place. #2. Over-priced. People who stay here are either conventioneers or particularly rich. And golfers. The course is nice so if you want to tee off every day disregard this rant. #3. Las Brisas Restaurant. The atmosphere was devoid of what Mexico does best: warmth. Too much posturing going on without much behind it. The menu wasn't very creative at those prices and since the restaurant is ON the beach, why not open a window or two? The dishes are too safe and the portions too much - wasteful. #4. The "casita". It's a hotel room rivaling that of any Motel 6's proportions, long & narrow. The balcony is a plus but between mosquitoes and noisy golf carts whizzing by - we happened to be placed right on the end by a bridge so whenever a cart with a load of people rode by, we'd hear a "weeeeeeeee!" and lots of laughing - I'd stay inside. The internet wasn't working and the decor is sort of depressing. All in all, just not very cozy. Don't be fooled by those glowing photos of a gorgeous room! Disregard if you're staying in an oceanfront suite. #5. The guests. The place is filled with business travelers and their spouses. These people are happy to be out of akron in february for good reason. Getting drunk at the hotel pool bar is par for the course here among this resort wear crowd. They just happen to be paying more for their drinks. Ultimately, don't pay this kind of money for the Mayakoba. It's a complete money suck. If you want to pay lots of money for great service, golf and beach time, manicured surroundings, and fancy digs, consider Barbados or St. Bart's.

Reviews.Title: “No worries”
Reviews.Author: DBS1950
Reviews.Content: We booked our stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba through a travel agent. Subsequently, after reading a number of negative reviews on Trip Advisor (which I did not learn of until after we booked our reservations), I became concerned as to what we had gotten ourselves into. Fortunately my concerns were unwarranted. The Fairmont Mayakoba was wonderful. The staff is very friendly and helpful. The room was of high quality (one note, the air conditioning condenser line to a number of units broke during our stay. We were offered the opportunity to move to another room, but as we were told it would be fixed within a day elected to stay. Unfortunately the air conditioning was not fixed within the time frame promised and we spent a couple of uncomfortable nights in our room). Other reviews indicated the concierge desk was never staffed. In our experience there was always someone at the desk , although it was impossible to contact them by phone as the line was always busy. But a quick walk to the lobby always resulted in their prompt attention to our problems and Monica and Ana were very helpful. The Mayakoba is spread out in a maze life fashion, but it is easy to get around and not too diffficult to learn the landmarks. The walk from the main lobby out to the beach is no longer than 10 to 15 minutes. Golf carts are always available to transport you to your destination. Another note, some reviews were critical of the gas powered golf carts because of the noise they generate. In our experience most of the golf carts are electric and very quiet, although there are some gas carts remaining. Now for the bad news. All of the reviews which were critical of the restaurants are accurate. The prices are extremely high and unjusifiably so given the quality of the food and the lack of choices. We ate in La Laguna and at the restaurant at the beach and both experiences left a lot to be desired. We chose not to eat at the restaurant in the main lobby as the menu was very limited and not appealing to us. Our first meal was a buffet dinner at La Laguna. The offerings were prime rib and what amounted to chicken tenders for the meat dish. There were some desserts, tacos, salads, etc. The price for two people was $100 and again, given the quality of the food and lack of choices, was outrageously overpriced. Dinner at the beach was also expensive and the menu options were very limited. My criticism is of the menu and prices. The wait staffs were very competent and concerned that we enjoy our experience. If I had to guess I would say the Fairmont is aware of the issues in their restaurants as at virtually every meal four or five restaurant employees, including managers, would stop by our table to see if we were enjoying our experience. Unfortunately good service cannot make up for overpriced meals which lack flavor. Breakfast at La Laguna is a reasonable option with a $25 dollar buffet that offers good food and some variety. We did not discover the snack menu by the pool until our last day, but would suggest that this menu is more reasonably priced and offers greater variety. We ate most of our meals in Playa Del Carmen a 15 minute cab ride ($15) away. i would recommend the Madre Tierra on 5th Ave. We also enjoyed visiting Xcaret and Xel-Ha. Both trips were arranged by the Mayakoba's travel desk, I would recommend you speak with Inez as she was very helpful. One note, each of those tours really requires a full day to see and enjoy them , so leave yourself enought time. Also, if you make a resevation for the dolphin swim at Xel-Ha make sure which program you are signing up for. Not all dolphin swims are the same, they offer some different experiences and options and we were a bit disappointed that we ended up with an option that was not as optimal for us as some others we learned of after the fact. All in all I would recommend the Fairmong Mayakoba and the Playa Del Carmen experience.

Reviews.Title: “Overall - great, quiet resort”
Reviews.Author: Wee
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just came back from a 7 night stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba. I too read all the reviews (good and bad) posted here. Hope our experience helps you all! Resort: Beautiful grounds, pretty flowers and plants everywhere. Meandering walkways. I was a little concerned about the expansiveness of the resort as I'm almost 5 months pregnant -- walking is good for me but only if I feel like it :). Our room was halfway between the lobby (6 minutes max) and the beach (about 8-9 minutes) and that's not walking fast. This is the most we've walked to get to pools/restaurants/lobby but you get used to it and it's actually quite nice, in my opinion. Also, there are golf carts zipping by constantly or you can just phone from your room to get someone to come by. Because everything is spread out, it's very peaceful and quiet. If you want to be bumping into people all the time, perhaps you should be at an all-inclusive that have all their pools/restos/etc...grouped together. If we could change one thing, it would be to have the main pool area and the beach area closer together -- we felt like we had to choose one over the other because of the distance. Beach: It was very skinny but still great sand. I think I saw about 50 nice chairs (get the teak-like ones with the pads - phenomenal). Was windy the day we went so we didn't go into the water. was very relaxing though and the staff was accommodating. the other days, we went to the main pool for a couple hours at a time (was closer) Main Pool: Very classy with little twists and turns which created privacy spots for 2 to 4 people. Staff would come around with a little fruit kebab or a eucalyptus eye wrap (both gratis). Kiddie pool is near the front entrance to the pool area and the adults area is closer to the back. Cabanas (probably between 5 to 8) were used mainly by couples with small kids but first come first serve, like everything else. The chairs are OK - faux woven rattan - would be better if they had pads. Plenty of towels everytime I walked by the towel cabana. Best thing was the numerous platforms in the pool where you could sit in a few inches of water and tan, read, etc... Room: We had a deluxe casita on the ground level. Very pleased with our room (looks like the photos on the hotel site) but the bathrooms with the natural light were even better than the bedroom. I'm not a bath person but took 4 baths with their Penhaligon "quercas" bath products (even hubby liked the bath products and he's a Dove guy). Shower can fit two and has a bench. Separate toilet. Has two closets and 1 safe that worked fine. Would recommend more hooks to hang up swimsuits, etc...Also, would get a second level room just to use the patio. Since ours was ground floor, we didn't go out because we have tall plants (privacy) all around. No issue with bugs. Always had plenty of bottled water left by staff for brushing teeth although we still bought our own. Food: Only had breakfast, couple lunches, and one dinner at the resort. We had a car so preferred to head into Playa Del Carmen. Sure the prices are not cheap ($24USD for full breakfast buffet) but it's comparable to any luxury resort. Lunches were about 17 USD per person. Dinner at La Laguna was ok priced as well - quality was OK there but we were tired and didn't want to head into town. Someone was raving about their guacomole by the pool - in my humble opinion, it was just OK, needed more salt and some lime to kick it up. Overall, we're happy we rented a car as we left the resort at least once a day. Valet is 14USD/day. Golf: Hubby and I played golf - a lot of golf. Total of 11 rounds. It's a very nice course. If you're a guest, it'll cost you around 159 USD + tax to play before 1:30pm. If you play after (twilight), it's about 105USD all in. Carts are included. We played so much that they let us pay twilight rates for our last round at 10am one morning. Staff at the golf course were really nice people. Always smiling, always willing to help out. Service: Always pleasant, always warm, the staff at the Fairmont does a great job in making you feel welcome. Does it have the polish and efficiency of a Four Seasons? No. But they make up for it with their friendliness. Case in point: We were going for a 2nd trip to the breakfast buffet and had to wait a couple minutes for made-to-order eggs. When we walked back to our table (literally 15 ft away), we realized that the staff had assumed that we had already left and they then cleared our table and reset it. It was quite funny and when we pointed out what had happened, we all started laughing. It was no big deal (they even put my husband's sunglasses away) but they still apologized profusely. I know this is a lot of info but I find it helps to be specific about certain details, especially those that are important to me! We really enjoyed our holiday although we normally meet more people at the resort. If you are seeking a more social/interactive trip, you may want to rethink. If this is a getaway/honeymoon/family time, then I think you would love the serenity, beauty and warmth of service from this resort.

Reviews.Title: “I didn't ask for a tarantula in my room!”
Reviews.Author: willy777boy
Reviews.Content: My wife and I chose the Fairmont Mayakoba as our honeymoon destination. We specifically requested a room on the highest floor, as we have visited Mexico before and while we have always enjoyed its beauty, we are aware that there are creatures in the jungle. We were given a room on the 4th floor, at the top of the hotel. On the day before our departure, my wife went into the bathroom, and exited screaming that there was "the biggest bug she ever saw" in the bathtub. When I entered the bathroom, I immediately exited it, and closed the door in shock. I re-entered with a camera and took pictures. I told my wife to call for help immediately, there's a tarantula in our tub! 15 minutes later, a security employee equipped only with a clipboard entered. He saw the tarantula, and told us "he was scared". He called for reinforcements. We spent the rest of the day lugging around our valuables while waiting for a room without a tarantula. We also spent about 2 hours arguing with different customer service representatives about what we thought reasonable compensation would be for our ruined day. For a 5 star resort, they were not understanding of this frightening experience. We left the next day in disgust. We will never visit another Fairmont.

Reviews.Title: “Best All Around Resort You Can Find”
Reviews.Author: Suncatcher101
Reviews.Content: First of all , I have read every negative review written about Mayacoba on this site and I have to say those who wrote them are absolutely wrong~!!!!! My Wife and I have traveled to some of the finest and most exotic resorts in the world and I challange you to find a BETTER resort ! When I look for a resort to spend a vacation I look for nice beaches , big modern ,clean rooms , a big pool or pools ( big enough that you arent fighting for pools chairs (aka Ritz in Puerto Rico, or Palms in Turks and Caicos) and good restuarants and also some culture or activities to do close by . This place has IT ALL!!!!! 1. SERIVCE ( 5 stars +++)- off the hook, nicest people and best services I have EVER had , no joke !!! 2. BEAUTFUL LANDSCAPE (5 Stars)- between the beach ( which that stretch was voted #1 by Travel channel in the world) and the plush but natural beauty of the overall grounds and views of thegold course, just amazing. Not to mention there are like 7 pools which you feel like its your own pool b/c they are sooo big and there is usually no one else around so you are catered like a king by the pool guys . 3. Great BEACHES !!(5 stars )! enough said, the area voted by the Travel Channel #1 in the world , not to mention snorkling right off the beach . 4. Great Food ( 4 stars ) - hey Im not saying best food ever , but I stayed here 7 days and nights and didnt have a bad meal once . You wont find anything better anywhere else around there . Id not to mention the surounding area is great to explore , I recommend renting a car from the airport ,costs about $14 a day fora nissan sentra, cab from airport is about $80 so u do the math , alot cheaper to rent a car . Things to do in the area: Playa del Carmin-is about 7 mins away , so def go there and go to 5th ave and get dinner Tulum - Mayan ruins on the cliffs , about an hour drive, recommended during an overcast day if u have one . Slavateca- ZIP LINE - awesome, zip through the tops on the an jungle on nothing more than a pully and a wire . so much fun !!! ask the desk for details about 40 mins away in the jungle

Reviews.Title: “Excellent in every way”
Reviews.Author: Likes_to_TravelAtl
Reviews.Content: We just returned yesterday from our stay at Fairmont Mayakoba, and I could not disagree more with the negative reviews. We went with a fairly large group for my husband's business, but also had a lot of alone and free time. Normally, the reviews are a good indication of how a place is going to be for me, but not this time. First of all, the entire place is amazingly beautiful. The grounds are in the middle of magnificent foliage, trees, and all types of plants. It is almost like a jungle feel, but much more manicured. The resort is spread out, but that adds to its attractiveness, and it really isn't terribly far to get to any one place. The people who are complaining about how long it takes to walk everywhere must be extremely slow walkers. We walked to the beach several times from the other end of the resort, although we didn't need to because golf carts came by every few minutes asking us if we needed a ride. It probably took us 20 - 25 minutes (max) to walk from our room (close to the lobby side) to the beach side. We chose to walk almost everywhere because we were admiring the beauty of it all. We did take the golf cart back from the beach to our room, though, because by the time we were done with the beach side we were tired and there was always a golf cart available, ready to take us back. We also had the option of riding bikes if we wanted to. We ate at most of the restaurants and had room service ordered in. The food was always delicious. The people on the phone told us exactly when to expect the food to be delivered (about 45 - 50 minutes from the time we ordered. Not horrible, especially considering that we knew when it was going to arrive). Our dining experiences at the restaurants were always great. The servers were more than friendly (even walking me to the bathroom when asking where it was) and accomodated any special requests we may have had regarding the food. The breakfast buffet and the lobster & scallop fajitas at Las Brisas were my favorite! Service is not the fastest, but we were there to relax and take it easy, so we didn't care at all. Most Carribean restaurants are that way. There are several pools to choose from, and they are all beautiful. One even has a water slide. If you get thirsty or hungry there are always wait staff available, ready to serve you if you don't feel like moving. The entire atmosphere is designed to be extrememly relaxing. If looking for more action, the lively town of Playa Del Carmen is not far at all. The front desk can arrange a cab in no time. We went there to shop one day and for the nightlife one evening, and had a great experience both times. We were treated like royalty at the Fairmont. I didn't even open my own door half the time because if a staff member saw me coming he/she would rush to open the door first. It was very clear that they would bend over backwards for us if needed or requested. Everyone was always all smiles, extremely courteous, and more than competent. We have traveled quite a bit, and have stayed at different types of hotels and resorts. I have to say that this trip was definitely in my top 3 of favorite trips.

Reviews.Title: “If you want a fabulous "luxury" vacation, DO NOT come here!”
Reviews.Author: Andrew W
Reviews.Content: Per previous reviews and the Fairmont name (not to mention the rather high prices), I was expecting a Four Seasons-level experience. What I got was a FOUR POINTS by Sheraton stay. If that. First of all, this is no boutique resort. It is a big, sprawling CONVENTION hotel. It's a mile from the lobby to the small stretch of not very appealing beach. It's a jungle hotel with a little beach... it is NOT a beach front hotel. The beach, however, is no prize. Small, not terribly clean stretch of sand. Never went into the ocean once. Having gotten used to luxurious, trouble-free stays at hotels like the Four Seasons (which, at the price you pay, you should get), this place was nothing but PROBLEMS. All of them were eventually resolved, but only after TREMENDOUS effort on my part. I felt like I was at work trouble-shooting all day. NOT RELAXING. Not at all. Let's start with the airport pick-up. It DIDN"T happen. Even though I had confirmed it twice with the hotel's concierge. So I had to call the hotel on my cell in the heat while I was being hounded by dozens of drivers at the airport. NOT a luxurious experience. No excuse for it. The room category I reserved (on-line) turned out to be totally different at the hotel. Got an upgrade, but only after the first room I was shown was flooded and I had waited an hour for my bags to arrive from the distant lobby. The room I ended up getting was quite nice, but NOT air-conditioned. The A/C never worked properly even after calling maintenance. I had to keep the thermostat at 63 degrees to get it to work. Which meant the room was FREEZING. But better than suffocating. And, if you turned off the A/C, the room starts smelling like the swamp the hotel is situated in. The food was not good. And really expensive. I ended up using room service most of the time. The wait was always 45 minutes, mostly because the distances the staff have to travel are SO LONG. The big pool complex shown in the photos is beautiful. But it's half a mile from the beach in a swamp. Exceedingly hot and humid. No breeze at all. You are always overheated at this hotel, even in the cool part of the year. And they DO gouge you for bottled water. It's really tacky. You're always taking the smelly, diesel-smelling golf carts everywhere. (There are a few bikes, but never where you want them). So you have to wait for the carts in the heat. (And if you want to go to the gift shop or the deli or the beach or the lobby, you have to factor in about 40 minutes for the trip. At least). They actually have "bus stops" for the carts. Also, beware of the rooms along the "busway," because you will be hearing the noisy carts and smelling them night and day. Kind of odd for an eco-resort. If you take the boat trip from the lobby to the beach, you quickly see that the hotel was built very cheaply. Big chunks of marble are missing from the buildings and the wood has already lost its stain. The whole place looks like it was thrown up in a hurry. My favorite part of the visit? Getting TRAPPED up on the roof of my casita for an hour at 9 pm because the turndown service locked me out of my room. I was literally trapped 3 stories up. Fortunately, I had the room's cordless phone with me (only because of another problem... the staff had turned off the heat to my private plunge pool... which took 1-1/2 hours to correct). After calling the front desk 4 times in one hour, I finally demanded to speak to the manager. 10 minutes later, I was freed. Having spent most of my time either experiencing problems or trying to work them out, I did get to know a lot of the staff. They were, with only one or two exceptions, very nice people. But that doesn't make this a hotel worth visiting. Their parting gift? After check out, I was overbilled $200. I didn't even bother contacting them. I no longer have ANY fight left in me. Ultimately, my hotel stay was really just dreadful. I will NEVER stay at another Fairmont. One final tip. This "Riviera Maya" area is really not worth visiting unless you see the Mayan ruins, which actually made up for the unpleasant hotel stay. And, beyond just the Fairmont, all the new, genuine luxury hotels they are building (including the Rosewood & Mandarin) are on small slivers of land that stretch from the highway to the beach (about a mile and a half in most locations), with most rooms sitting in the flat, hot jungle. If you like great beaches, this area is not for you.

Reviews.Title: “Extremely motivated staff”
Reviews.Author: AstridfromFrankfurt
Reviews.Content: We are from Frankfurt and I stayed with my husband and my ten months old son 2 weeks in October (excellent weather, if that is the regular rainy season we are only coming back during this time) The staff was extremely motivated and helpful in all matters we had (it is true, there are not much drawers but ask for hangers - you will get loads!) It is also true that the resort is extremely vast due to being situated in a nature reserve. Therefore you have two resorts in one: The main building and most of the Casitas in the middle of the mangroves with stunning pools and the Casitas down by the beach on fab white sand...so bring time to get around (but for God sake you are on holiday!) We used their Babysitter Service every day during the afternoon so we could play golf (our son loved the girl and she brought him from time to time to the kids club, which is obviously for older children but nicely done with lots of toys also 1 year olds can enjoy) After one week we graded up to a Beach Casita which was ideal for us with a child sleeping during lunch time. We sat by the private pool and had Dinner in Las Brisas in the evenings with Babyphone (meals were not always convincing but complaints always led to improvment). As the Beach Casitas have a Butler Service we asked for Inroom-Dining and they set up a table on the terasse in front of the Ocean with candles and rose petals (food was so and so ....like always with room service) Overall: come if you look for a quiet and slow holiday without heavy sightseeing, on fab white beaches with lots a nature around and excellent service in beautifully designed surroundings!

Reviews.Title: “an expensive disappointment”
Reviews.Author: carolineBethesdaMd
Reviews.Content: I booked our vacation for our family of six back in March 2006. We travel frequently, and I was excited to stay at a brand new property in a booming area. Unfortunately, I was very disappointed with our stay at the Fairmont Mayakoba and would not recommend it to anyone: The first issue was that the private transfer that I had pre-arranged with the hotel failed to show up at the airport upon our arrival. We waited for 30 minutes and then hired a company at the airport at a more expensive rate. When we arrived at the property, one of our two “signature casita” rooms was not ready, so we parked our bags at the available room and took the long trek to have lunch at Las Brisas at the beach. We waited 50 minutes for our meal to be served, even though there was only one other occupied table at the time. The quality of the food was just ok, and VERY expensive. When we returned to our room we found that the key to our adjacent room was not delivered as promised, and we had to wait an additional 45 minutes, after several phone calls to the front desk. Each time during our stay when we would call to the front desk or concierge, we were placed on hold, or transferred to voicemail, and our calls would go unreturned, or in one case, returned at 1015pm!!! Housekeeping did a fairly good job, although we had a light bulb out in our bathroom and the light switch on the bedside lamp literally burned out (and burned my fingers when I tried to turn it off!). Upon our departure, I had to leave notes for housekeeping on the various fixtures that needed attention. Also worth noting is that the pools were repeatedly out of towels (even at 11am). Ultimately, the food at the restaurants was so mediocre and expensive, and the service so slow that we ended up taking taxis (US$60 r/t for our family of six) into Playa del Carmen for most of our meals. By the way, restaurants worth checking out in Playa include: la Cueva del Chango, Tango Taco and El Diablito. We spoke with other guests who felt the same way about the food and service – a real disappointment when you’re paying top prices (US$799 per room per night). This resort is too big, its layout cumbersome and tiring to navigate, and the service is slow or non-existent. My entire family could not wait to leave and get back home, and that’s a very sad thing to say about a very expensive family vacation.

Reviews.Title: “Low Occupancy; Still Lots of Problems”
Reviews.Author: Ricardita
Reviews.Content: My family and I stayed for 3 nights mid-December when the hotel was 25% full. But even with a low number of guests (and an apparently high number of staff), the service was poor in most areas and departments of the resort. We waited for golf carts which came 30 minutes later, the wait to be served in the restaurants was interminable, and numerous repairs in the room (the safe and lamp, among others) were requested, some of which were addressed, some of which were not. The food was high in price and low in quality. Housekeeping was good, the grounds, as stated in previous reviews, are lovely, and the whole eco-concept of the hotel is admirable. We can only hope that service improves.

Reviews.Title: “shame on fairmont”
Reviews.Author: kojack
Reviews.Content: Shame on the Fairmont for putting out such a poor product and shame on me for not analyzing the prior responses on Trip Advisor.The Fairmont is not a class act.It doesnt compare to the Four Seasons in Punta Mita,Costa Rica,Nevis,Provence,or other sophisticated resorts such as Las Ventanas,Esperanza,or Raffles Canouan.It is a convention hotel with relatively small rooms and a very mismananged staff.Even more disturbing are the gross distortions expressed by the hotel.For example,the hotel claims it is a beach resort.It is not!A beach resort implies a real beach operation.It is not just a few lounges on a dirty beach.The hotel claims that its cart system is efficient.In reality,all it takes is some rain and the whole system breaks downThe food at the hotel is bland and the restaurant staff is clueless.An hour wait for the wrong sandwich is the norm.I wish I was exxagerating but im not.The hotel private signature rooms in the beach area are small ,on the ground floor,and have views of a swamp, but the hotel has the nerve to charge$ 800 a night.The so called butler service for this room would not be necessary if the hotel was well managed.Stupidity runs rampant at the Fairmont! A typical example is the fact that bottled water is given to each room,but the restaurants charge 3.50 for the same bottle.So---- if you want to take your pills in the morning carry your free water to the restaurant.What angers me the most,are the trip advisor reviewers who receive substantial upgrades and write raving reviews about this hotel.I challenge those reviewers to pay the real prices for those rooms,when the hotel is more than 50% full and give the same praise as before.For those who are looking for boats in a canal system that hardly ever run,rainforest shower heads in each room,and some pretty foliage,by all means go to this fairmont. However,if you are looking for great rooms,great service,and fine dining,don't you dare think about this Fairmont.In Feb the PGA is having an event at the El Cameleon golf course.Managers from every Fairmont will probably be coming to Mayakoba.Youll probably hear all great things about the resort on the Golf Channel.Dont believe it.Once the outside world leaves,the same general manager and staff will remain and until that changes this hotel will still be a less than average resort

Reviews.Title: “Mixed bag”
Reviews.Author: XSverdad
Reviews.Content: My wife and I were there from 1/2 - 1/9. The setting, service and just about everything else about the Fairmont is spectacular . . . except the food, which is poor. We ordered Pizza via room service one evening/morning and promptly received what looked like a frozen or "instant" pizza, which tasted horrible. Similarly, my wife ordered a burger at the beach-side restaurant and the patty looked very similar to a pre-fabbed McDonalds patty, only larger. However, the texture and flavor were worse than the ones you get at Micky-D's! Keep in mind that the cost of this stuff is truely astronomical. These two meals were substandard at any price, however. The other meals we had ranged from "very good to OK". None of it was spectacular and none of it justified the price. Also, of particular note was the sea/beach. The sea water at the beach had brown suds and occasional trash in it! The neighboring beach had trash/garbage dumped and/or washed-up on it - some of it neatly bagged and some of it not! Not at all the hot ticket for romantic walks/swims along/in the carribean. On a scale of 1-10, we rank the beach experience a "5" - and this takes into account the wonderful beach service we got from the Fairmont employees. Although its a very nice place with very nice people, we would not return.

Reviews.Title: “Beatiful grounds but needs better management”
Reviews.Author: fivestars26
Reviews.Content: We had high expectations for a Fairmont Hotel, epecially paying a rate of $700+ for essentially the cheapest room in the house! We had the misfortune of arriving during their busiest week since they opened. The first night, when we arrived, all the restaurants were fully booked, with the exception of the one that was a buffet. When we decided to get room service, we could not get any one to answer, and repeatedly got transferred to the front desk, whose response was try again in 15 minutes! When we finally placed our order, the food took more than one hour, not to mention my seafood pasta, was one of the worst pasta dishes I have ever had.
